The game and concept it self is very good and can be fun. I go to unlv for 3d modeling and sculpting, so this game allows me to mess around & let my creativity loose. However the community & servers make the experience absolutely suck, to start theirs favoritism by the devs. Awhile back I made a build that was inspired by one I found in the workshop, mind you i know its annoying to copy builds and call it your own. I guess I made the mistake of not giving him credit which i forgot since I didn't put much thought to the description. When I made this i was inspired didn't want to just edit his build, I wanted to make my own from scratch & spent quite some time on it even had friends watching and they made their own versions. changed everything from logic blocks,dimensions, color, block complexity, only thing similar was the open cockpit and how the wings worked which I programmed. Came back to find it was shadow banned "not showing on profile or search" thought it was odd so I looked at the report on discord just to see the guy crying on how it looked the same but not really he was mainly upset that the cockpit and wings were too similar? mind you it wasn't something complex that no one could do... Since hes one of the devs favorites they chose to shadow ban my build... After this I just decided to take down all my builds and not post any new ones.
 I started this game on xbox, was very excited with the intention of endorsing it by making videos for youtube to get more eyes on the game. I moved to pc {steam] a few months back to record how I make most of my builds but because of how the community is that excitement died down. I have 1.6k hours on steam and about the same on xbox but since moving to steam I've had so many builds stolen where kids just stand under you while you build; just to take your builds when u get out of build mode, post it and call it theirs. Over time I saw the devs talk about this saying "sharing is caring" so never really got that upset. What's upsetting to me is that now they're shadow banning builds out of nowhere only because favorite individuals are reporting & to me that's not ok its clearly favoritism while the rest of us go through this often and just get ignored. If you want to solve the whole "copying" problem add a lock build mode system so no one can edit our builds. Till this is addressed I'm staying off this game.

I think that this game is overall pretty good. Unless you like at least one of two things: 1) Complex/high part count builds and 2) part-on-part interactions. The complexity limit is very easy to hit being at 700, and complexity doesn't mean part count, it means how many different interactions have to be processed for a part. And the part-on-part interactions are terrible and glitchy. I come from Scrap Mechanic, where the whole thing is part-on-part interactions and massive builds, so coming to this where sliding two blocks against each other messes with physics I had a pretty negative view of the game, but after looking at it objectively I have decided to write this review, both as a comprehensive comparison of this vs. Scrap Mechanic and a warning to other people who may want something different.

1: Physics
Both games are centered around physics, yes, but different aspects of it. In SM it's mostly about the smaller-scale interactions, like two surfaces sliding against each other or parts pushing against each other. In TM, it's mostly part-environment interactions, such as lift, drag, and friction.

2: Building
The building style is vastly different between the two games. In SM it's mostly first-person with third-person mostly being for driving and looking around. You also place each individual piece with very few pre-built parts, like joints and servos. In TM, it's almost exclusively third-person, with first person barely being an option. You mostly use pre-built parts, like wheels and wings, and connections are done automatically in most cases.

3: Modding
Scrap Mechanic pretty much survives off of the modding community. There's so many mods that are almost essential to the point where it's impressive to see a complex build without mods. In TM modding is more manual and less encouraged, though not discouraged either, and it's rare to see anything using mods, though the game survives on it's own and doesn't really need it.

4: Developers
The developers for TM are heavily involved in the community and regularly interact with it. There's always news from them and they respond to questions pretty frequently. SM feels almost abandoned, with the last update being November 2023, and the last significant update in late May 2023. News also stopped entirely in June on all platforms. Everyone in SM is so used to this that we've pretty much given up hope of hearing from the devs altogether.

5: Worlds/Levels
In SM, the worlds/levels are procedurally generated by default, or maps can be custom-made. Things like railroad tracks or roads can also be added directly to the map so as to increase performance. In TM, there's the default levels, which are pretty extensive, or you can manually add custom ones.

6: Damage
Without mods there's no part damage from environments in SM, whereas that's one of the biggest aspects of TM.

Overall they are incredibly different games that work entirely different. If you want pre-built parts and environmental physics get TM, if you want part-to-part interactions and more small-scale interactions then get SM. If you want to know that the devs exist get TM, if you want built-in modding get SM.

Excellent game for adults and kids.  I haven't found anything nearly as good that is both interesting and complex and forgiving with its damage/respawn mechanics.

I am an engineer with a grade school daughter and we love playing this together.  It is essentially what I wished Lego worlds was (also a great game for kids, but lacks complexity and the vehicles always felt like a sadly missed opportunity).  It is also a great step up from that for kids as it adds dynamics, controls, and design complexity without being aggressive or punishing.  I expect to buy the DLC as we finish levels and maybe make some custom maps.  I expect this to be our "go to" family game for the foreseeable future.

Pros:
-Mixed adult / kid coop friendly
-Nice visuals for a family friendly game
-Great depth of inventive, goofy, and awesome designs
-Flexible control options for complex actions

Cons:
-Likely boring for those not interested in building/physics
-Occasional physics glitches

Wishes and Possibilities:
As an engineer who loves controls, it would be an unparalleled game experience to be able to add sensors and programmable control schemes (PID, etc.) based on some simplified scripting (perhaps a DLC add-on?).  This would allow complex walking robots, self-leveling hover jets, etc.  It would also be marketable as a teaching tool, and far more fun than most.  If Flashbulb is interested, reach out and I'm happy to work with you.

Trailmakers is a good idea for a game but executed poorly.
I've owned this game for a good few years now, and I've been somewhat keeping track of new updates and what's added to the game. Sadly it seems like the devs only want to focus on expansions and dlc packs, they call it free updates but in reality it's just a "Demo" for what you can do in the expansions, while the base game suffers from a lack of real content. A new campaign level would solve that issue, it can just be a repeat of the one we have now, crashing on a planet, and starting from scratch again, they wouldn't even need to add new blocks to the game, just a new area to explore while you build up again.

The main thing you do in the game is BUILD, but the builder is a buggy mess, it works enough to work and that's it, it leaves so much to desire it's insane. The vehicle builder pretty much needs to be completely redone so building something simple doesn't take you 20 minutes of fighting with the game to put a single block where you want it.

It would also be great if the physics engine for this game was also updated. During my last play-through of this game it was extremely frustrating at times having to reset my vehicle over and over again because it kept breaking itself. I'd swap my vehicle and have to spend 5 minutes or longer waiting for the game to decide when it actually wanted to work and spawn my vehicle in correctly so it wouldn't break instantly for the 20th time in a row. 

If they just fixed the builder, the issues with the physics bugging out, and added a new campaign level, the game would be worth buying, but in it's current state unless you want to also spend over double the cost of the game to buy the expansions with it then it really isn't worth the price, even on sale for anything less than 75% off.
Fun to develop creations and test them.

The game is great but I cannot use the majority of workshop vehicles because they have decorations I do not have, so the game does not let me spawn them unless I delete those parts. to get the credits for those parts I need to either play the campaign or play races, I just want to play sandbox and enjoy creating stuff but there is no way of getting those decorations without playing the game in a way I do not want to play. For me, this is the biggest problem and needs to be changed. I've looked for other ways of getting credits but all are unavailable to me or I just play campaign. Please change this, I don't want to give this game a negative review.

Physics are WAY too janky to support a racing game mode, to the point I keep randomly hitting invisible physics geometry on the road that instantly brings me to a stop. Some of the vehicle blueprints they give you in the free-roam junk scavenging gamemode control so poorly they give me little confidence that it's possible to make an equivalent that works well. There is fairly little control over the function of objects, and even just including gearboxes would do a LOT to improve the usability of vehicles.
Could be great but I have a feeling it suffers from the same issue most vehicle building games do, where most of their users are children who want to shoot at each other online so most of the development goes into catering to them rather than making something decent.
I was really hoping to have a decent vehicle building game with actual objectives to give me any reason to build specific kinds of vehicles, but this isn't really it. I've had far more frustration than fun in my time playing it.

EDIT: Went back a year later on this game. Whatever updated happened, worked. I played it out and had a great deal of fun with it so I'm updating my review to positive.

I spent probably 5 hours making some just for a stupid bug to delete all of my work. What happened was, I was making an auto controlled hover vehicle, eventually I finished it, and I was really proud of myself. I decided to finish making a old manual version of it, I finished all of the controls for it and overwrote the old manual hover vehicle. I made another small change, but this time when I saved it, it automatically tried to save in the auto version of it, and I wasn't paying attention to it, and clicked save, and realized just after I saved it that it overwrote the auto version's save slot, and there is no undo save feature in the game, so about 5 hours of my life wasted because the devs only add game play, not any extra features that could be really helpful.

It's is an amazing game, with unlimited possibilities and you can build whatever you want! I, personally like to build logic-y creations and WAY over-complicate them, but you can take the simple route or you can choose to make stuff just because it looks cool. That's all I want to say, and that's the end of this review.

This revised review is made in response to the developers response to my initial review as it made clear how poorly explained my gripes with the game were. My first review was poorly detailed and just got straight to the point and is unedited in SECTION 1. SECTION 2 consists of the response given by the developer. SECTION 3 will be a much more detailed response to the developer after having played for 185 hours and purchasing the Airborn DLC. SECTION 4 will consist of closing thoughts and a more detailed review of the game. 

SECTION 1

This game is as bare bones as it gets. The campaign consists of picking up spheres and placing them in new locations over and over and over and that's it. They actually require you you to pay for more game via over priced DLC that should have just been included in the game as updates.  Just look at the bundles and DLC for this thing and you will see. Trashy, super trashy.

SECTION 2

karsestar  [developer] Posted: 2 Jan @ 9:54am
Hello Cohollow. When it comes to single-player campaigns "Stranded" is the only free one at the moment with the much bigger "Airborne" being a paid expansion.

The focus of Trailmakers is not being a single player campaign game however, but a sandbox building game and we believe (biased of course) that the game has a ton of free content in that regard. Sandbox maps and the vast majority of blocks are not behind a paywall as well as the Space Sector map - which is our biggest map to date and also free.

Just wanted to clear that up. ğŸ™Œ

SECTION 3

"When it comes to single-player campaigns "Stranded" is the only free one at the moment with the much bigger "Airborne" being a paid expansion."  -  Yes the "free" (we'll come back to that word shortly) content is indeed much smaller than the paid expansion, to the point of the expansion having more actual game and requiring you to buy it if you want to have anything to do in the game at all.

"The focus of Trailmakers is not being a single player campaign game however, but a sandbox building game and we believe (biased of course) that the game has a ton of free content in that regard."  -  I literally bought and paid for the game, that is not "free." How charitable of you to allowing me "free" access to the content of the game I spent money on. Yes the game is about the sandbox, of which there is very little without the DLC.

"Sandbox maps and the vast majority of blocks are not behind a paywall as well as the Space Sector map - which is our biggest map to date and also free."  -  The games biggest and most useful sandboxes ARE behind paywalls. Ya I'm not going over what "free" means again. Your Space Sector map is indeed the biggest on account of it being SPACE. There is a huge empty space of nothing for you to pilot your spaceship through. This isn't big content, it's empty content. I explored all there was to see in less than 2 hours.

SECTION 4

I don't need to explain how ridiculous the claims of "free" content is do I? Again, I PAID FOR THE GAME. The games main menu will constantly give you pop ups on the main menu to entice you with the DLC. Every menu you open when constructing your creations has blocks that are locked to you unless you pay for DLC, but they make sure you can see what you're missing. The Stranded map is made purposely tiny and restrictive to ensure you will require the Airborn DLC and the High Seas maps in order to make good use of any kind of air or sea based creations. Even land base creations have little room to roam in the not at all "free" sandboxes provided with initial purchase. There is even a paid DLC called the Space Voyager Pack that you will want if you expect to get the most out of the base games "free" Space Sector map. Of the more than a dozen skins in the game, only 3 are made available for the initial price of the game with the remaining are split between 2 paid DLC that only consist of skins. Even your character has a whopping 2 outfits and the other SIXTEEN are locked behind and split between 3 different DLC. If you want to buy the entirety of the game it will cost $84.13 Canadian which roughly translates to $62.84 for the U.S. dollar. No, this game is not worth that price and it's shady way of attempting to slowly manipulate and suck the customer in to further spending just to have enough game to properly interact with is slimy.  Buying the game is just the entry fee (FEE not FREE). The DLC has an absolute mountain of paid DLC content compared to what you get for buying the game. You'd be crazy not to purchase some... Like the dev said "The much bigger "Airborne" being a paid expansion."

Outside of my gripes, the game itself is one of the best examples of games of this kind. The physics are fun, the creations are fun, and everything functions relatively well baring the odd bit of jank here and there. Nice aerodynamics go a long way. It has one of the simplest and most efficient building systems I've played with and still has a great deal of creative freedom despite keeping things simple and minimal. 

Only buy this game if you think it's worth the price of a AAA title or if you are ok with having access to only the tiniest and most boring sliver of this games content. If you wish to experience anything significant in terms of campaign, exploration, combat, progression or anything at all approaching actual gameplay, I highly recommend factoring the Airborne DLC into your purchase. Also note that I only detailed this games more egregious and predatory failings to keep things shorter. 

I would like to thank the developer for responding to my review and openly displaying their deceptive tactics and for giving me cause to give this game a much more thorough and comprehensive review. It's even free, aren't I nice?

Edit: With 1882 hours, I still highly recommend this game! I am really happy with the build UI. it is easy and efficient to quickly build a vehicle. the vehicle is suspended in a build box which allows you to freely rotate around(useful when making tweaks to the bottom of your creation) the parts are all neatly organized as well. and the best part you are not clicking through menus to get to the part you want, instead, the parts are conveniently located on the bottom of the screen where it is simply a matter of clicking and dragging the piece you need.

But what is nice about this game compared to the others i've played, is that the game outside of building is also ready to explore. you can drive through caves, plains and mountains. hover over lava pits, and fly though a volcano! or if you'd rather swim, the oceans are also full of life(depending on the map(Treasure island)) You can even go to space in the base game!

I recommend all the dlcs too! from my experience with them they are full of good content and customization!

Banjo Kazooie Nuts and Bolts but without that Rareware charm.

Plenty of options for vehicle customization, which can lead to lots of complex and interesting builds

Most of my criticisms will be aimed at the Stranded campaign mode, since that is where most of my time has currently been spent.
It kind of sucks.
Very empty map with vehicle parts spread out that you have to transport to various checkpoints to collect. 
The parts are fairly heavy and require you to engineer a solution to transporting them. Often times my solutions will mess with the collision and break certain parts, or mess with the balance and make transportation really slow and awkward.

The materials your vehicles are made out of, in my opinion, are way too fragile. Making mechanical arms for lifting parts out of the hinges can often break themselves if they reach certain angles, trying to bump parts like with the starter bumper cart is a very slow process, but is also annoying because of how often the bumper breaks off immediately.

You find a magnet that is essential for hauling the parts, but a lot of the parts are far too large for the magnet to pick up or manipulate, even if you have a really heavy vehicle with loads of engines on it. And even if you do get a bite, half the time something breaks immediately.

I know there are other campaings, and multiplayer, but meh. I liked banjo because I was adapting to interesting environments with challenges in them and progressing through a story. Multiplayer is cool, space travel is cool, but I wanted a mode where I could progress with parts and stuff, and the mode that they have is just a boring sandbox.

I'll try them, because I like the gameplay thus far, but this island campaign was really annoying.

In something like Banjo Kazooie, you had all this charm, great music, characters, and missions thrown at you while you were progressing. 
In this campaign, your just in a big sandbox with a bunch of heavy parts everywhere your vehicles will inevitably suck at at moving. At least in Banjo you could pick up various parts with your wrench and snap them into place on your vehicle, and you'd add various parts to make it not fall out. Maybe if there were a mechanic like this where you could manually interact with the parts it wouldn't be as bad. 

In Banjo, unlocking parts naturally matched a sort of progression that aligned with certain missions and environments. Here, parts are kind of spread out at random. Also, the majority of the parts suck. They're mostly wedges and stuff to shape your vehicle with.
So imagine building a sick submarine, and painstakingly making a design that doesn't sink or break to pick something up, then the only real reward is a servo motor, and the other parts are like wedges and "power core" upgrades which just let you place down more engines.

It'll leave you feeling like you wasted your time, with little reward involved.

Not to mention the amount of paid DLC that lock certain items behind a paywall.

I think the game is objectively a good game, especially since it feels a niche that a lot of games don't so I'll give it a recommendation, but these aspects I mentioned are worth noting

The most accessible vehicle builder. It's quick and easy to build just about anything, especially post-Airborne and Spacebound. New parts make it possible to throw a basic VTOL together in five minutes. You can also go complex with logic and make an entirely different beast. Wheels and collisions between parts can be janky, but it's the polar opposite to something like Stormworks where you have to build your entire engine, transmission and program it all. Stormworks can do more, but be prepared to learn programming languages first. Not the case here.

While it offers a bit of fun, the game feels unfinished, and is clearly still in serious development. After collecting parts with friends, we quickly got bored. The sandbox experience is simply not enough -- we are players that enjoy a structured challenge with specific goals.

More importantly, this game has the smell of one of those that never reaches a complete state, while nevertheless evolving slowly and perpetually (largely by free labor provided by modders). In my opinion, this development strategy isn't legitimate for a game you've released. The fact that it's common for sandbox games to limp along in this way doesn't make it acceptable to me. Forever Early Access isn't a state I'm willing to pay for, and if I'd known that's what I would get, I'd never have bought Trailmakers.

This system probably works well for people with LOTS of time to devote to a game as a hobby rather than as a library title, and an endless appetite for returning to the game they've played to find it transformed. I don't have either.

Update: It seems like my prediction has proven true so far. There are now spacecraft and more parts, but no incentive to return to the game as it will probably be substantially transformed yet again after a while. [i]That is what a game in development looks like[/i]. I don't support the model of perpetual EA.

16 Hours in. Had the game for a bit more than a year now after I bought it with some spare change in 2018. To me, Trailmakers is entertaining but not fun. It's a game I get on when waiting for friends or something to pass time and I can't really say it holds my interest all too well. Gameplay revolves around building your own vehicles to traverse the landscape (obviously) or to solve puzzles / complete challenges. For instance the game's 'story' consists of going around and picking up scrap and power cores to rebuild your rocket and escape, which isn't all that bad for a game of this caliber but the map is BARREN so there's not really a visual aspect other than the grass which looks kinda pretty if your settings are right but other than that the visuals in Trailmakers aren't too spectacular.

I believe Trailmakers has potential. The physics need a bit of work because (from what I've seen) vehicles exceeding 20 blocks attempt to defy the laws of gravity and fly to space (though you'll never get there seeing as you'll spontaneously combust after 2 seconds) and in my opinion the game needs much, much more content for me to consider this a worthy $25 purchase without a sale.

I enjoyed the game for the first 10-15 hours; building land/water vehicles is fun.  The game is /really good/ at being a land/water vehicle builder.  The game is shit at building aircraft, but that's the next 15-25 hours and most expansions.  

Why?
1) There's NO KEY REBINDING. To clarify: You /can/ rebind individual parts' functions like "bend right" or "make the engine go/reverse", but you /cannot/ rebind GAME functions -> You cannot rebind the Build Menu (B), the Switch Vehicle button (R), Exit Vehicle (F), or the Camera Mode (C). It's lousy when your vehicle needs six degrees of movement /and also/ need to toggle engines and the booster and the tractor beam.

2) The aerodynamic indicators (lift, draft, center of mass, etc) ONLY SHOW when the GAME thinks it's worth showing you; you cannot manually turn them on/off:  No, switching "indicators" on/off doesn't fix that, the game still decides what you see when it feels like it.  This means that you can't predict problems to fix ahead of time, so you get really far into the design before the game feels like showing you the fundamental problem with it that'll require you to rip the whole thing apart again to fix.

3) The helicopter propellers fritz out for no reason and explode.  It didn't seem to matter what I did - it just kept happening.

This game was /really good/ in the opening hours; in the first half of the map.  Then it became a steaming pile of crap real fast.

This is a great Lego builder game!
I predominantly played the story mode called 'stranded in space'. The premise is you have to find orbs and move them (using your Lego designed vehicle) to specific locations that will give you new blocks to use and allow you to progress further to get more blocks, until you can build your spaceship and leave the planet. 
This game was a ton of fun!! The progression and pacing of the game is great. I was using a 360 controller and it worked great for the vehicle building, which is a rather good and simple system to work with. 
It is awesome all the locations you can traverse, from normal ground, low traction ground, above water, under water, and in the air (gliding or flying). The flying vehicles can be difficult to design with balance so they have some premade basic flight vehicle blueprints.

I highly recommend this game for creative building minds that like a collectathon.

This review is positive because I'd score the game 5.1 out of 10 with 4.9 and below being negative.

This game leans massively into it's DLC which means you'll want to get the game on sale with DLC to enjoy it fully.

The game has a psuedo-aerodynamic physics system. It's a poor physics system for 2 reasons, firstly the game offers some utility settings such as "powered steering". This deliberately reduces the turning ability while travelling at high speed. If you are travelling at 100 kph and attempt to do a 90 degree turn, under real-world physics you'd be fighting against 100 kph worth of momentum/inertia, thus it will be hard to steer. Trailmakers uses a multiplier instead. [b]That's not a physics simulation[/b], and basically results in you fighting against the poor physics simulation at either end of the speedometer.

Secondly, the devs want you to buy the DLC which means the DLC parts are straight up superior to the base game parts. As an example, in the base game your best attempt at an aeroplane doesn't involve any of the rotational blocks for propellers and none of the wing parts have any flaps which makes them uni-directional. Even the dev's prefab blueprints for vehicles look and handle like utter garbage. The helicopter doesn't even use the helicopter blades! But those pipes, with the exact same weight value as the large lego-like bricks are invisible to the aerodynamics system. Once again the weight, momentum and inertia of your vehicle is pointless so long as you add those lovely DLC parts.

If you buy the DLC I'd recommend the airborne expansion and [b]never touch the base game campaign.[/b] In the time I played this game I obtained all the blocks in the base game and any DLC blocks that were included into the base campaign. I built a single vehicle capable of driving on the ground, taking to the skies, diving into the ocean and being able to return to the ground. It was ugly, clunky and most of the time I had powered steering disabled. It massively helped the steering issues but still felt like I was fighting against the physics. Then I jumped into the airborne campaign which has wings with built in flaps, new types of jet propulsion, an actual plot, NPCs, quests... You get the picture.
fun if u like making and building stuff

Well worth it for me.

Bought it on Steam sale and didn't spend any more money on upgrades or bonus packs.  The campaign was fun and challenging enough.  Building vehicles is the core strength of the game.

- Vehicle building starts simple and gets progressively more complex
- Allows for creative problem solving
- Variety of geography requires different solutions (cars on land, boats and subs for water, planes and hovercraft for air, and rockets and ships for space)
- Graphics and physics engines are realistic and very responsive

I am sure other people have dived in far deeper and enjoyed the download packs and other challenges the game offers.  For me the solo campaign was worthwhile and fun enough to cover the $13 purchase.

A truly amazing building game for those who like to use their brains to build complex functioning machines, or even the few who like to create not-so complex but instead wacky devices that, for some reason, against all logic, work. While there is a decent bit of DLC behind a paywall, everything you need to enjoy the base game is very much still there. Personally, I'm incredibly picky about giving games reviews, but this one is very fun to play (even with friends!), and I heavily enjoy making all sorts of vehicles. Every dollar i've spent on DLC helps support the devs, too, so I see no problem forking more money for a good game! Do I wish it wasn't behind a paywall? Yes... but does it bother me? No, since its truly not that expensive. Overall, very good game! Just add tank treads sometime soon pls

this game is great for passing time, destroying stuff, and making cool contraptions! i've only had a few problems and that is there isnt tons of big wheels, there are 3 kinds. truck tires, monster tires, and drag tires. we need some tires bigger than the monster tires.
Even after 2 semiwhole years, this is a increedibly good game.

this is one of my favorite games got it for 6 dollars on sale  and it is awesome I try to play it every day and all dlc seem good, space voyager pack is a little overpriced otherwise It is tied for first place against tsw4 and fh5
This Game is really fun you can build interesting Cars I would recommend this game to people who like Sandbox,Exploration,Multiplayer Games.

The game is fun for a casual vehicle building game. Its got aerodynamics, for planes and buoyancy for boats and submersibles. You build using blocks like legos and gadgets like hinges, pistons, and servos. Logic gates are there but are a hard pass if you know how logic works and don't won't to relearn how the devs think they work. Logic needs a rework. Dare I say copy what other games have done like LittleBigPlanet 2 which in my opinion has a superior Logic system. The Devs left out a few key logic blocks like the NOT, NAND, XNOR, and NOR gates. You have to use the OR, XOR, and AND gates to fill in the blanks which is tedious and takes up block count and space on your builds. They also felt the need to leave out key blocks like a 1x1 cube. Their argument is they have a 1x1 pipe junction. Just make a 1x1 cube so we can have better LOOKING BUILDS! Trying to make builds that have a good looking form is hard with very little wedge selection and of course that forbidden 1x1 block. Building cars with suspension is something you really have to study and perfect. It's not as easy as throwing the actual suspension block on there and hitting some hills. The base springs and suspension pieces are terrible and your car will shatter on the slightest jump. You shouldn't need to engineer an entire chassis using servos and hinges to make viable suspension which in turn causes lag and the vehicle physics to slide across the ground when not driving. not to mention the off chance it explodes and send you to jesus but here we are. To build anything actually functional and fun for the most part takes time and maybe a few tricks here and there. Tricks and workarounds I wish we didn't have to take. This game could be so much more but it just isn't. With all that I'm still going to be playing the hell out of it because there isn't another one like it.
Fun to build crazy vehicles of all different terrains!

i just love this game no matter what it never gets boring.
take it from me i have played this game for over 1000 hrs
It's fantastic. With the new spacebound update, you can build and do truly anything
A tad bit grindy to start off. But the physics are a lot better than the graphics lead you to believe.

Easy to pick up and start building.

The campaign is a bit slow but still fun - with 98 hours clocked, I'm still only 45% of the way toward fixing my ship. This is not the selling point of this game for me though.

The sandbox building and racing are really where I have found the most fun.  
I lose hours fine tuning my vehicles to improve on performance or beating my best times and climbing the leader board. 

The multiplayer works well.  It can get chaotic at times but it's loads of fun seeing what others create.

Looking forward to getting into the space update!

Highly recommend if you are into sandbox building games.

I have 600 Hours on this game now, The devs of this game definitely know what they're doing with the updated and content that the game has to entertain people interested in engineering and taking their imagination to the extreme. You can play the game however you want and in any style you'd like. The campaigns are also very good and keep you entertained for a while. The content just gets better and better as the devs learn more and listen to their community as any good team of devs should. Thank you devs for this amazing game
A very fun lego-style construction and physics playground, with lots of opportunities for multiplayer shenanigans.
I love the new Space expansion pack, It makes it so much better.
At first, that game was a bit boring, but since the space-bound update, [b]IT'S BEEN AMAZING![/b] Definitely reccomended, 11/10.
its fun you can make anything you want and if you like building things that work or making bloxy art or just exploring then this game will be fun for you plus it still gets updates That are FREEEE

16 hours in: hands down, this has been the best $20 I've spent on an early release game since vanilla Minecraft. Even in its unfinished state, I can't see the horizon of boredom with this game.

I rather enjoy the campaign mode that forces us to innovate in order to progress further. ie basic car -> powerful car -> jet-assisted car -> hover car -> Jet-assisted hover car, and so on. 

The selling point however was the inlusion of multiplayer. Sharing silly explodie gifs with your friends is one thing, but blowing up together...now that's the real deal. 

If, like me, Besiege carved out a special place for creative problem solving (+5 explosive chance) in your heart, I suspect Trailmakers will appease nicely. However, where TM decidedly takes the cake in streamlined building and intuitive creation it was certainly not meant to fulfill the same mahem and violence as Besiege. *nudge nudge* need more weapons :D for science!

**While we're on the subject of adding things--would sincerely insist upon a CG marker (centre of gravity). But hey, trial and error is fun too.

And, I haven't even gotten to the racing mode yet! brb

tl;dr more fun than digital legos, more practical than your high school physics class

**UPDATE**

-unlocked all 'chieves
-found the maximum possible ground speed in the sandbox (turns out the size of the sand box is the bottle neck :D)
-now we're going to space, fam.

Full marks, guys. Ya'll are killin' it.
This game is very fun. Would recommend. If there was an option higher than thumbs up it would be higher than that. Trust me I have over 100 hours in this game.
its a fun a good game

This is like Lego but super charged. Fantastic game and easy to loose yourself in creativity. Highly recommended. Only downsides is some of the physics, not super reliable when building complex vehicles.

Great game, well worth the money, just wish there was a mobile/switch version

Great game and fun to learn more realistic physics!

Trailmakers is an exceptional game that combines the thrill of exploration, the joy of creativity, and the satisfaction of engineering. It provides an exhilarating experience for players who love building and driving their unique vehicles in a vast open world. From the moment you start the game, it becomes evident that Trailmakers is something truly special.

One of the standout features of Trailmakers is its robust building system. The game offers a wide array of parts, ranging from simple blocks to intricate machinery components, which allow you to create vehicles limited only by your imagination. The intuitive building interface makes it easy to experiment, iterate, and refine your designs, empowering players to construct remarkable and functional vehicles. Whether you're building a speedy sports car, a rugged off-road truck, or a flying machine, the possibilities are endless.

Once you've crafted your creation, the real fun begins as you embark on exciting exploration missions. The game presents a captivating open world that is teeming with diverse environments, challenging terrains, and hidden treasures. From the lush green forests to the towering mountains, each area is beautifully designed and invites players to venture further and discover the wonders that await. The sheer size and variety of the world ensure that every journey feels unique and engrossing.

What truly sets Trailmakers apart is its emphasis on physics-based gameplay. As you take your creations for a spin, you'll witness the realistic physics at play, making the driving experience thrilling and unpredictable. The game rewards players who design balanced and well-engineered vehicles, as they will navigate the terrain with ease and conquer the challenges they encounter. The sense of accomplishment when your creation overcomes obstacles and performs flawlessly is incredibly rewarding.

Trailmakers also offers a delightful multiplayer mode, allowing you to share your creations and collaborate with friends. The cooperative building and racing experience add a whole new dimension to the game, fostering creativity and teamwork. The ability to challenge and race against your friends' vehicles adds an extra layer of excitement, turning every session into a competitive and engaging event.

Furthermore, the developers of Trailmakers have shown exceptional dedication to their community by regularly releasing updates and adding new content. This commitment ensures that the game remains fresh and vibrant, keeping players coming back for more adventures and challenges.

In conclusion, Trailmakers is an absolute gem of a game that blends creativity, exploration, and physics-based gameplay into an unforgettable experience. With its outstanding building mechanics, breathtaking open world, and endless possibilities, Trailmakers offers a true sandbox of fun and discovery. If you have a penchant for engineering, exploration, and imaginative play, Trailmakers is a game that deserves a spot in your library. Get ready to  unleash your creativity and embark on an epic adventure like no other!
Great building system, devs are still updating the game. good game i recommend

Seriously though, this is one of my favorite games. The building system just *makes sense* and the environments are fun to explore. The game is a real labor of love.

When I first reviewed Trailmakers back in 2018, I was captivated by its versatile game mechanics and the sheer joy of building everything from airships to hovercrafts. Fast forward to today, and my admiration for this game has only deepened, thanks to the incredible journey it has taken.

Since my initial review, I've delved into the fascinating world of modding. Creating mods for Trailmakers has been an enriching experience, allowing me to add my personal touch to the game and share it with this amazing community. The creativity and possibilities feel limitless, and it's thrilling to see my ideas come to life within this vibrant world.

What truly stands out for me is the developers' unwavering commitment to the game. Their continuous support and updates have not only enhanced the gameplay but also fostered a welcoming and innovative environment for players and modders alike. It's a testament to their dedication to the game and its community. If you haven't already, go ahead and check out the discord, the community in this game is something special.

Trailmakers has evolved remarkably over the years, and being a part of this journey has been an absolute delight. It's more than just a game for me now; it's a canvas for creativity, a community of like-minded enthusiasts, and a testament to what passionate developers can accomplish. Here's to many more years of building, exploring, and modding in the incredible world of Trailmakers!

The game is often focused on encouraging creative thinking and testing engineering skills. Players can design their own vehicles using various parts and explore different environments. This gives players a lot of freedom and creativity. The game makes it possible to create complex and functional vehicles by combining simple parts, making gameplay very enjoyable. Each part serves a different purpose, allowing players to customize their vehicles in any way they want.

Visually, "Trailmakers" features a colorful and vibrant world. The game's graphics and environment design create an atmosphere that encourages exploration. Players face different challenges as they navigate the open-world environments, which adds to the excitement of the game.

However, the game does have some technical challenges. Especially when creating large and complex vehicles, there can be performance issues. This can negatively affect the gameplay experience for some players. Also, the repetition and similarity of some of the missions in the game can sometimes create a monotonous feeling. In other words, the game has some weaknesses in terms of variety.

The developers are constantly trying to update the game and value player feedback. This could bring improvements and fixes in future versions of the game.

All in all, "Trailmakers" is a fun game that stands out for its creativity-based gameplay and offers the opportunity to test your engineering skills. However, some technical issues and repetitive gameplay elements should be noted. The game could be an interesting option for players interested in the concept of building and exploring.

In one word: pointless.

I trudged through the tedious and aggravating 'stranded in space' campaign which consists of building barely viable vehicles to push around rocks to unlock new parts so you can build bigger and better but still barely viable vehicles to push more rocks for more parts. At the end you blast off into space. Woohoo.

I got this game for the building potential, and while there is a lot of potential there, I quickly became bored because there's nothing worthwhile to do with anything you build outside of the campaign (unless you're into racing), and the campaign was dull. On top of that the selection of blocks is very limited and there's no 1x1 blocks at all. Cosmetic blocks are locked behind coins that you are barely rewarded with for repeatedly performing tedious, boring tasks.

The physics are kind of aggravating, and the blueprints the devs added generally work terribly as well. You know there's a problem when the devs can't even build vehicles that work well. If you build a car with the center of gravity off to one side the car will literally spin in a circle at a standstill.

People have uploaded some amazing builds to the workshop, but there's nothing to do with any of them.. drive/fly around in creative mode for a few minutes, get bored, call it quits. To make matters worse, you're not going to be able to actually build most of those things unless you have ALL of the DLC.

I found that the majority of the time when I closed this game out after a play session I just wasn't happy, I just wasn't enjoying it no matter how hard I tried.

Would strongly recommend the game and DLC's.

Edit

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

It's 2023. The game has seen it's new space update. I tought I'd give it a try. I changed pc, so I had to install the game again. Suprise! No cloud saves. Saved blueprints go in the abyss if you don't upload them via the game's workshop. Lost priceless vehicules that I spent 10-20 hours in. I'm honestly unimpressed at this point. In a game where the goal is to make a vehicule, having no cloud saves grinds my gears and makes me sad. I would assume that a game like this would have cloud saves.

The reason for the negative review, is the dev's continued ignoring of community issues and requests for now going on 4 years. The game is quite poorly optimised on top of that and gets low FPS dips, hitting 100% usage frequently even with a 30 series Nvidia card. 

[h1]Lack of Objectives[/h1]
The worst issue which consistently ruins any motivation to come back to this game: We still have no real use for our vehicles, except to "collect" spheres in campaign repeatedly [i](or drive over boxes in the new DLC)[/i]. There are no challenges like moving items or other vehicles around (cranes/trailers/aircraft etc, blowing things up, any other creative minigame you can think of... literally just collect things to get more parts to collect things, that's it. You can do "race" challenges too, but you just race yourself and the leaderboards are just full of people exploiting the physics to top it daily, easily. [i](Flip a hoverpad upside down)[/i].

[h1]Fragile Vehicles[/h1]
A personal nitpick issue of mine is the vehicle's strength/durability. They will literally collapse in to pieces as if it was an IRL lego truck you threw off a table - the slightest bump will destroy a tank/car/boat/sub/plane completely. This takes out much of the fun because whatever you do, you have to keep spamming the repair key to reset your vehicle just because your wheel grazed a tiny pebble on the road [i](literally, not exaggerating there)[/i].. This should at the very least be a slider for hosted matches because it sucks that your monster truck is destroyed by pebbles.

[b][i]Edit: This DOES now have a slider... but only if you host a sandbox game. In the campaigns which are the only content with an objective, you still have to deal with vehicles collapsing as soon as they touch anything.[/i][/b]

[h1]DLC Practices[/h1]
The Dev's don't seem to care about fixing issues, fulfilling requests literally made since the launch of the game, or optimising performance. They are however, pushing out DLC that no one asked for and which doesn't add anything except a map with no objectives, so no reason to build anything [i](The collectables on the map are in the base game except 2-3 new ones per DLC)[/i]. They also release tonnes of cosmetic "camos" for blocks which are the equivalent of a single flat texture copy-pasted over blocks, these are DLC as well.

[h1]Lack of Community Interaction?[/h1]
They do building contests to feign interaction with the community but that's about the extent of communication with them in my experience. This game may end up the same way as the likes of Nuts & Bolts which at least actually had reasons to build lots of different types of vehicles and I'd argue is superior, plus has a great soundtrack. This game by comparison is sadly just a cute little sandbox with little else memorable to it.

[b][i]Edit: They do have a public Trello where people can vote on features to be included, but these are not often user-submitted feature requests. Usually, they're what the Dev's add to it and were likely going to add down the road anyway. You effectively just vote on what you think should be completed first.[/i][/b]

[i]If anyone wonders about my hours played and yet still leaving a negative review, bear in mind I've replayed the campaigns 3 times each because of replaying them with friends, I highly doubt most people would find that entertaining on their own and if it wasn't for those friends I'd have left this game after the first completion roughly 10hrs in because there is nothing else to do with your vehicles.[/i]

UPDATE: The first sentence is now false, I do not own all DLC, I quit buying them.  I also now regret buying them, I do not however regret buying the game.  I still do not recommend it to anyone looking for what I was.

This game is wonderful, I own all DLCs and do not regret it, however I am leaving a negative review considering when I move on from this game, I'm not usually in a good mood.

TLDR;  Devs won't add blocks the community has been asking for (for years).  Complexity limit is fixed unless modded.  No control settings unless you change them for EVERY build you create.

This game is about building, yet the devs refuse to add basic blocks, for instance there is no 1x1x1 block.  SEVERAL blocks that should exist simply don't, there are slopes with matching corner pieces and slopes without matching corner pieces.  There is no consistency in the availability of blocks.  This fact has also become a meme of sorts as the devs have acted in the past as though they had intentions to change these things and yet never have.  The devs have even said that adding those parts would "alter the game play experience" and make building too easy, however I have to disagree with this.  If you have an idea in your head and the only reason you can't build it or have to find some work around is the lack of a block the devs have neglected to add to "make the game harder", it's hard to enjoy your "game play experience", and leads me to turn the game off.  I have hundreds of hours in this game when it very well could be thousands.  Limit blocks from certain game modes, yes, but don't neglect to add them into the game at all.  Lack of freedom is why I never stick around long.

Your build is limited to a certain complexity as if you're playing on console.  Every ones PC is different in some way, complexity should be available in the settings menu for single player and server menu for multiplayer.  A mod should not be required.  Every game I start I load up the mod (thus opting out of high scores and subsequently a large portion of the "game play experience") and set my complexity to 2000, I have never had a single issue and I have had to turn it up on occasion.  My "game play experience" is 30 to 60 seconds in a UI every time I load into a world.

Default controls can not be set.  If you place an engine, it will be mapped to W/S, place a thruster, maps to space.  This should be configurable in the settings.  It's a waste of build time when certain things you place ALWAYS get mapped to certain buttons and you ALWAYS have to change them because you can't change the defaults.  It's to the point I'd almost be happier if everything spawned in unmapped, at least then when I didn't want something mapped I could just not open it, rather than opening the settings and clearing the default mapping that would have been incorrect for me had I even wanted it mapped.

MY PERSONAL BLUNT OPINION: Seriously? I'm limited to certain blocks "to make the game harder" and the biggest challenge you can think of... IS PUSHING ROCKS AROUND!?... *sigh*... I want this to be one of my favorite games, and it easily could be, but the contradictory nature of the devs and their "reasons" for not listening to the community on mulitple occasions scares me away.  Not to mention the recent release of High Seas which feels more like a tech demo than proper DLC.  I love this game, but have little faith in the devs, and thus, the games future.

CAMPAIGN called: STRANDED IN SPACE
Played: March 2023

I have completed this game twice now.  And Trailmakers does have an actual ending to strive for by collecting the necessary parts to build an escape Spaceship rocket.  I love having an end game type scenario to shoot for in a game of this type!

Not knowing what to expect, I was pleased to play a game with no enemies in this vehicle builder game.  I had just previously played TerraTech that I liked a lot, but was ready for a similar game with no fighting.

You start out on a central island with very few parts to use to build a vehicle.  But the game gives you some basic vehicle templates to use, provided you have found the necessary parts to build it.  So the search for vehicle parts begins...

As you drive, boat (or later fly) around and find rocks which contain a single unique building part, you need to initially push them into the Recovery Drone's beam.  These recovery drones are stationary beam-up locations around the map to gain a building part from the rock-looking objects scattered throughout the map.  Interestingly, and differently from TerraTech, once you gain that part you can use as many of them as you want in your vehicle builds.  

The pieces snap together like Lego(TM) parts but have a strong number of configurations that can be tweaked.  For example, red lights can be placed on the back of a vehicle and configured to only light up when pressing reverse making them brake lights instead of always on.  You can tweak the speed of pivot parts that are attached to wheels if you find yourself turning to quickly and rolling your vehicle too easily.  Stability can also be accomplished by just making your vehicle wider.  Further configurations of control parts include a Toggle checkbox and Speed setting which you wouldn't want on your car's turning wheels, but would want on an attached Tractor Beam to hold up red collored explosive volatile rocks so they don't drag on the ground as you make your way to a Recovery Drone to turn it in.

Now, these rocks come in different sizes and shapes.  In fact, some are simply huge for anything other than a very large truck with weights in the front or back to counter the weight of a Tractor beam with a large rock attached.  Furthermore, some rocks are volatile meaning they will explode if you jostle them too much, and in turn, blowing up your vehicle.  If destroyed, or flipped upside down from carelessness, a simple button press will not only right your vehicle but fully rebuild it too.  It is very easy to just test things and see what happens, resetting your vehicle immediately if things go wrong.

As for the default vehicles, I disliked half of them.  The first one is fine but you should put some blocks on the front's sides to "gather" rocks more easily on the starter island.  The only other default vehicles I really liked were the "Hovercraft", "Gimble Car" and "Monster Truck".  The Monster Truck needs to be extended though in the back to have six total wheels and counter weights in the front to take the weight of the largest rocks in the back.  All the others needed small to large tweaks, especially "The Sub".  The in-games default submarine was a nighmare to control for me.  I ended up downloading a yellow submarine from the Steam Workshop, but still had to make it bigger for the large underwater rocks and changed the control scheme to match the button presses I wanted to use with the Xbox controller.

This is the first game that I've ever played where my use of gamepad vs keyboard/mouse was about 50%/50%.  The Gamepad was used to drive all vehicles, but the keyboard turned on/off control points and the mouse was used in build mode.

Great vehicle builder game with low stress.  I highly recommend it.

This is by far the best game I have ever played.

The building mechanics are incredible, letting you create anything you can imagine. From starships to amphibious cars, helicopters to carboatplanes, you can create just about anything you want in this game. The only limit is the complexity limit and your imagination. All you have to do is drag, drop, rotate, and configure, and you have placed a block. Every part in the game has more than one use, from using pistons as cannons to using steering hinges as doors. Not to mention the mods, of course, which can let you change gravity, complexity, size, and thrust. NOW you can make anything you can imagine.

An fun-ish game with some really annoying jank in the controls and most interesting parts locked behind DLC. Similar to Besiege or TerraTech, in that you're building machines to solve puzzle tasks - but in a way it is like the best of both games, with the low stakes and unlimited builds of Besiege and the item hunting/unlocking of TerraTech. However, it's lacking some customization options that seem really obvious - for instance, you can't bind keys to activate specific wheels, and you can't bind anything at all to the numpad. Fun when it works, but you're gonna get frustrated.

Possibly the best physics sandbox game out there.

50+ hrs so far, most of it in the campaign where you collect scraps for more part to get other scraps (Some under water, in sky islands, in swamps) all pushing you to build in new way or to upgrading a build you made previously to withstand the new conditions. It is the most satisfying "puzzle solver" I have ever played. 
The Sandbox mode is incredible giving you free reign on all the blocks (Minus a few minor ones from dlcs, given you don't own it) within 3 great maps. One is dedicated to racing of all types, the other is more of an exploratory island with flaming hoops and ramps all over. The last one has all sorts of goofy things to get into a few being a battlebot arena, a [strike] rocket leau- [/strike] soccer court, and a jousting platform.)
The Devs constantly holding building competitions and overall super active. On sale this is an absolute steal, but beyond worth the standard price.

it's a really good vehicule building game with pretty realistic physics engine that let's you easily create cars ,planes ,submarines ,hovercrafts ... basically any vehicle you can imagine; creativity can take you
 far.

Overall a fantastic game! The devs are active and keeping up with the game. Physics engine can be busted at times but what physics engine isn't?

Building a vehicle is easy, building a "good" vehicle is a bit of a challenge depending on your build style. Everything you do to your vehicle has consequences. (Bad aerodynamics, weight, engine choice)

Additional parts are in the game you have to purchase with in game money. Money is earned throughout the game and isn't required. The parts you have to buy are just for decoration, and is not required to build vehicles.

Complexity limit is a bit hard to navigate with 700 points max. Most complex physics parts like servos and hinges (anything that effects the physics engine) usually cost 5 points, while most basic blocks use up only 1.

This game is truly a really good sandbox building game, But im not 100% sure if its worth it or not.
The issue is that they lock a ton of stuff behind DLCs, for new players who are just buying the game it can be pretty expensive to buy everything at once. While i understand the devs have to make money so they can continue developing it, its still frustrating that you have to spend another 25 dollars for the 2 DLCs that are NEEDED for a much better building experience. Then there's the Decals packs which aren't needed but are extremely handy and your gonna wanna buy them.

As you know this game is a multiplayer sandbox so you can join servers with other players. The community isn't too bad but it can be a little frustrating at times. In some servers some people will kick you just out of the blue or you kill em 1 time boom kick, sometimes don't even ask you to stop or try to reason. If your into pvp some people make these cheesy pvp machines that completely annihilate reasonable builds. Then there players that build lag machines and spam builds,  but on the other hand its fun to interact with the players in the servers who are decent players.

SO,  id say if your willing to fork off more than twice the games actual price to play id say go for it, its a great game. Even if you don't mind not having all the benefits the DLCs offer then its a good game and id say its worth the price But if you aren't i cant recommend this game to other people who have an issue with the things ive listed

This game is great. You get a part, drag it, drop it. Simple as that. You can build anything you want to build, and the feeling when you get it right is just golden. Planes, boats, cars, tanks, anything you set your mind to you can build. You can take jumps, have fun on multiple maps, drive race courses with friends, and oh so much more. Just a sandbox game to have fun, make friends, and build. If you're one of those people that want to get a sandbox game where your creations only stop at your creativity, but you think that it would be extremely hard to learn and build, then try this game. One thing I love about Trailmakers is that even now at some 1093 hours in the game, I still learn new things about it all the time. I would absolutely recommend this game to anyone, and I do mean anyone. Anyone can learn the game and enjoy it. If you like vehicle combat, few games are better. If you enjoy first person shooter games, then build one in Trailmakers. If you enjoy games where there are gargantuan maps to explore, not to mention questing for objects all over some of those said maps. If you are a person who loves to fly a plane, and make realistic aircraft just as I do, then there is no game better.

But there is one huge caveat. Autoaim. Basically, there is a thing that aims your guns for you because a lot of players have a skill issue and begged the devs for easier dogfights. It makes dogfights unrealistic and not fun. For any players that like realistic aircraft with realistic dogfights, I gotta say I'm not fully sure I can suggest it. Now, people can turn autoaim off, but no one really does. Online server dogfights are simply not fun anymore, there's no real skill involved. The whole rest of this review was before autoaim, some 200 in game hours ago. At this point I don't really like the game a lot, since I like realistic dogfights in this game. I just wish that Trailmakers was back to how the game was, when it was fun.

Definitely one of the best pure sandbox experiences out there. Similar to Scrap Mechanic and even Garry's Mod, Trailmakers puts you in a world where you have access to different vehicle parts where the aim of the game, like with any sandbox, is to build.

The game has a campaign mode which I thoroughly enjoyed and consider perfect for a sandbox styled game (unlike Scrap Mechanic survival) and with two excellent DLC campaigns available, this game is sure to keep you entertained for a while.

unlike many sandbox games, the modding community is not as large which may simply be because its not as necessary. That said, there are still many shared player builds available for download on the workshop.

[h1] Trailmakers: fun for all ages.[/h1] 
The perfect game to have fun with your younger sibling, nephew, little cousin or whateverâ€¦

[h1]Graphics:[/h1] 
Graphis are cool and fun; the vivid colors and lego-styled blocks make this look very familiar to any block-building afficionado.

[h1]Tutorial:[/h1] 
The tutorial is a must; the game is not that complex, but getting the hang of everything is certainly difficult without it. Itâ€™s a good-quality tutorial, too. 

[h1]Controls:[/h1] 
Main controls are as basic as it gets, but since a big part of the game is customization, vehicle controls can get as complex as you make them. You can set thrusters, hydraulics, etc., with the keybindings you prefer; you can even set more than one element attached to the same key and activate both at the same time, in a symmetrical or asymetrical manner.
As mentioned before, I suggest playing the tutorial and fooling around a bit in test mode.

[h1]Environment & Setting:[/h1] 
The environment is a big part of the game; overcome obstacles as you explore your surroundings and improve your vehicle. Floating islands, raging vulcans, deep sea scavenging... You will have to explore the various biomes and terrain types in order to fulfill your mission of getting back home.
The game either happens on a "foreign planet" that you will have to explore during camp or in different sanbox scenarios that allow fun and chaos to happen within the creative realm of block building, racing, and dangerous stunt competitions.

[h1]Music and sound design:[/h1] 
The sound design is good, and the music is decent, but nothing worth writing a whole paragraph about. The chill music is good for the building menu and such, and the sounds of explosion, throttle, thrusters, and engines are satisfying to hear and play with.

[h1]Variety of blocks and options:[/h1] 
The base game is already packed with stuff; more than 100 different block types will allow your imagination to flow and be cherished in a fun experience where only the sky is the limitâ€”a sky you can conquer with your plane engines and wings, of course! You can combine them as you want. I love using jet engines on my motorcycle-styled vehicle; it makes perfect sense! /jk
In case the basic blocks are not enough, you can always expand your inventory with the game's DLCs. I havenâ€™t tried them for now but might do so in the future.

[h1]Characters:[/h1] 
As far as I have reached in the game, there are no characters aside from you, the player, and your friends. You can customize the character a little bit, but nothing too special or extravagant. Very basic stuff; the characters are not the main focus of the game after all.

[h1]Gameplay and game mechanics:[/h1] 
Your little LegoTM person is stranded in deep space, and you will have to work to get back to your spaceship! Or you can spend your time improving your vehicle speed for racing maps, or even try the sandbox modes and fool around as you wish.
There are several game modes available in the game. Campaign, sandbox, and racing.
Campagin contains the basic "Stranded in Space" adventure.
Sandbox contains the "Danger Zone" , "Treasure Island" and "Test Zone". 
Racing contains "Rally" mode and "Race Island". 
There are more modes, like the "Airborne Campaign" and the "Airborne Sandbox" mode or the "High Seas Sandbox" mode, but you will have to pay for the DLCs to get them.
The "Stranded in Space" campaign is where you have to rebuild your vehicle to get back to the mother ship and is one of my favorites.
Within Sandbox, youâ€™ll find "Danger Zone" where you can perform dangerous stunts and truly test your vehicle behavior in crazy contraptions and dangerous terrains; "Treasure Island", where you will have to solve puzzles and seek the hidden treasures; and "Test Zone", where you can, well, test your vehicles and imagination.
Within Racing, youâ€™ll find "Rally" , where you can build your racer, win blocks and credits, and improve your vehicle to keep competing... Or Race Island, where you can do your best in Time Trials with your racer and such.
The building menu is intuitive, and once you build something you like and feel proud of, you can save it and rebuild it as many times as you like. Testing stuff with friends and giving each other ideas is part of the fun, but if you are not into that, you can even play some sort of "combat mode". A friend and I created a little base with man-controlled machine guns and missile launchers, and the other player had to fly around and try to bomb the F out of everything. Another thing we tried was making a mecha-sort of vehicle, and we failed while laughing our buttocks off several times.

[h1]Community and multiplayer.[/h1]
You can download and use other people's build and contribute your own to the game community. You can share and enjoy building with others online and have fun exploring other people's clever creations. Multiplayer is a big plus, but how the community is integrated is also quite clever and nice to have. You can join public servers or make your own with your friends.

[h1]The gameâ€™s biggest flaws:[/h1] 
The game seems to be a bit heavy and intense on hardware. My PC fans go crazy when playing the game. For reference, I use a Nvidia 1070 with a Ryzen 5 5600x and 16 GB of RAM.
It would be cool to be able to customize the appearance of the character just a bit more.
DLCs are not cheap, and they lock away a lot of content.

[h1]Conclusion:[/h1] 
Incredible fun experience, and even more fun with friends. When I donâ€™t feel like playing anything too complicated, Iâ€™ll just jump in and have some chaotic fun. Your imagination drives what youâ€™ll achieve and many problems have a huge number of possible solutions. There are several game modes that will allow you to explore different ways of thinking while building stuff and make you come up with new uses for the same block. Another great thing about this game is that it appeals to people of every age. Iâ€™ve played it with my wife and friends and will son play it with my young nephew.
This being said, if you like legos, building stuff, or vehicles, then buy the game and enjoy; in the meantime, Iâ€™ll be building my own Gundam.

This game has all the things I love about Final Fantasy Tactics in it.

In Tactics you design your class based on what you need.
In Trailmakers you design your car based on what you need.

In Tactics you unlock classes and abilites as you play that make it easier.
In Trailmakers you unlock car parts as you play that make it easier.

In Tactics you can spend thirty minutes customizing your team to beat the next battle easier to win.
In Trailmakers you can spend thirty minutes customizing your car to make the next part easier to obtain.

In Tactics you want to unlock the Monk class and then the Ninja class because they are the best.
In Trailmakers you want to unlock the underwater parts and then the flying parts because they are the best.

The two things this game need to be perfect are cloud saves and a mini map.

I didn't have very high expectations but OH BOY this game hooked me. It's full freedom to build a vehicle for the task you want BUT it's not only a sandbox game. There is a great campaign mode which is an open world where you collect parts to be able to explore further and build better vehicles. And also a race mode with a lot of different tracks that will test your driving skills with a lot of different types of vehicles which you can also fine-tune to each track.

And that's exactly the kind of objective-based gameplay I needed to enjoy a game like this. There is also plenty of templates for both modes which makes it so you always have something to start from if you don't know how to get started with new types of builds. And then there is the other types of vehicles like planes, helicopters [spoiler]submarines,[/spoiler] and [spoiler]hovercars[/spoiler]!! This game had so much more to give than I expected and I love it. And also the building works well like how much more can you ask for??

I only have a few criticism and QoL requests:

- The first plane race is pretty much impossible with the template place. You need to add some vertical tailfins to it.
- I wish setting a new score in a race prompted you to upload the car to the workshop so players racing your ghost can compare their car to yours if they wish to.
- I wish I could see the race leaderboards from the menu. It's annoying to have to load a race map and check the tracks one by one to see which one i have the most room for improvement on.
- I'm sure other players have done something interesting with it but logic blocks are very very limited and they quickly take a lot of room making it hard to be very creative with them. It's a little unfortunate given how much freedom you feel like you have for all the other parts of the building process.

This is an unbelievably slapdash effort. The first red flag is the lack of rebindable keys. The second is that having a controller plugged in breaks the entire menu, and you can't disable them in the settings (there's volume control and not much else). The server browser does not have a region filter, or even an indicator for ping.

Even on the construction side of things, nothing works right. You'll be wrestling with the janky interface all the way. Basic principles of physics are thrown out of the window, and basic information is not available to you.

For instance: in a game with a lot of aerial and aquatic exploration in its "campaign" mode, there is no indicator whatsoever for Center of Mass, Center of Lift, Center of Buoyancy or Center of Thrust.

This is but one of the many oft-requested features that the developers, sequestered away in the community discord that you can only suggest feedback in after 1 month(!!!) of lurking, have outright stated will never be implemented (like displaying ping in the server browser! or filtering servers by region!). 

Instead, they're working on a [b]paid expansion[/b] for a barely functional and nearly content-free game.

It's a shame there aren't more options for this genre. Avoid this one if you can. Hope something better comes along, because after all this time, it's useless to think this one is getting any better. Let it die in peace.

UPDATE: THEY ADDED CENTER OF LIFT AND MASS AS PAID DLC, YOU CAN'T MAKE THIS SHIT UP, JESUS CHRIST

It's not a bad game per se, but it isn't what I expected - I was hoping for a solid mix of light crafting and adventure, and what I got was basically virtual Meccano with very, very light adventure elements. On top of this, it's quite janky a lot of the time - sometimes certain transformations or light collisions would cause my vehicle to explode or fire off ragdoll style in a random direction for miles. I really hate the flying controls in the game too which meant I never bothered finishing stranded in space and never bothered starting the DLC, which is a shame, since I was so close to finishing the former, but flying is bad enough without using the tractor beam forget using it. There is a good chance I'm just not good enough at building machines, but truth is, I didn't really enjoy that element of the game - this is a far cry from (the far more recent and AAA) Tears of the Kingdom's snap things together and it just works kind of building (I know, unfair comparison perhaps, but I want to let people know what they're getting into) - it's a lot more technical, I think for the right kind of person - someone much more engineering-minded than me, it could be fun - but for me, who expected a mix of lighter crafting and more compelling adventure elements, it was pretty tedious. Maybe I'll change my mind about this game one day and come back to it, but I'm not counting on it.

Trailmakers is an exceptional game that has managed to capture the essence of both creative exploration and engineering in a delightful and entertaining way. Developed by Flashbulb Games, this sandbox adventure offers a unique experience that blends the thrill of building vehicles with the excitement of exploring a beautifully crafted open world. With its innovative gameplay mechanics, stunning visuals, and endless possibilities, Trailmakers has become an absolute gem in the gaming world.

One of the standout features of Trailmakers is its intuitive and robust vehicle-building system. The game encourages players to unleash their creativity by constructing a wide variety of vehicles, ranging from simple buggies to complex flying machines. The user-friendly interface and vast selection of parts make designing and assembling these vehicles a joyous experience. The freedom to experiment and iterate on designs fosters a sense of accomplishment as you witness your creations come to life.

The open world of Trailmakers is a sprawling playground that invites exploration. From lush forests to treacherous mountain ranges and mysterious desert landscapes, each environment is visually stunning and brimming with secrets to uncover. Whether you're traversing challenging terrain, racing against the clock, or discovering hidden landmarks, the world of Trailmakers constantly rewards curiosity and ingenuity.

The gameplay mechanics of Trailmakers strike a perfect balance between accessibility and depth. As you embark on missions and challenges, the game introduces you to a wide range of tools and gadgets, including thrusters, wings, and propellers. These elements add an exciting layer of complexity to the gameplay, allowing for thrilling aerial acrobatics, high-speed races, and even epic jumps across massive gaps. The physics-based interactions are incredibly realistic and contribute to the overall immersion.

Trailmakers truly shines when played in multiplayer mode. Collaborating with friends or competing against them in various game modes adds an extra layer of excitement and camaraderie. The ability to share and test your vehicles with the community enhances the social aspect of the game, providing endless inspiration and opportunities to showcase your creations.

Visually, Trailmakers is a feast for the eyes. The vibrant colors, dynamic lighting, and detailed environments create a world that feels alive and brimming with possibilities. The attention to detail in the vehicle designs and the smooth animations further enhance the immersive experience, making every ride an exhilarating visual spectacle.

Lastly, the developers of Trailmakers deserve praise for their commitment to the community. They actively listen to player feedback and consistently release updates and improvements, ensuring that the game remains fresh and enjoyable over time. Their dedication and engagement have fostered a vibrant and passionate community that further enhances the overall experience.

In conclusion, Trailmakers is a must-play game for anyone with an affinity for creativity, exploration, and engineering. Its intuitive vehicle-building system, breathtaking open world, engaging gameplay mechanics, and vibrant visuals combine to create an unforgettable gaming experience. Whether you're an aspiring engineer or simply enjoy the thrill of exploration, Trailmakers will undoubtedly leave you hooked for countless hours of exhilarating fun.

Buy it.
