This game has SO much potential. Its basically digital legos. To get new parts you must collect these balls of various sizes. HOWEVER, I did find myself running out of things to do and not really enough parts to access the other areas of the map. There is only one map and Ill be honest, it is PRETTY lackluster. If youre a decent engineer, this game never really feels "hard". The idea behind this game is SUPER fresh. Last I seen something like this was Banjo Kazooie Nuts and Boltz. Which was Xbox360?? Something of this genre has been LONG overdue. Would love to see new maps and maybe new parts? Again, the game gets very boring after about 9 hours. Collecting items seems to slow WAAAAYYYY down. A vehicle you built for 30 minutes is only really useful for the ball you built it to get. After that, there is no more real use for that vehicle again. Would be cool to have like some cargo missions to earn money for NPCs and have some parts in like a store for those coins. Again this game is SOLID but it REALLY feels like there is a LOT missing. Not a lot of replay value....

[h1] A fun, competitive game, with cool graphics, well-thought out mechanics, and a lot of decorating options, players receive coins for winning challenges or races, and can find chests that give you coins. [/h1]

A fun, [u]competitive[/u] game, with cool graphics, well-thought out mechanics, and a lot of decorating options, the game has a sense of accomplishment as well. Players receive coins for winning challenges or races. You can also find chests in the campaign that give you coins. In the campaign you unclock your blocks for your vehicle, The coins can be used to purchase decoration blocks for their builds. The game also features a leaderboard, allowing players to compete with each other and strive to be the fastest. And fun Easter eggs! Trailmakers is an incredible game that deserves a 10 out of 10 rating for its impressive gameplay, stunning graphics, and endless possibilities. From the moment you start playing, you'll be hooked on the game's immersive world and the freedom it gives you to build and explore.

The game's construction mechanics are easy to understand, yet offer a great degree of complexity and depth, allowing you to build all sorts of vehicles and contraptions. Whether you want to build a car, a plane, or a robot, the possibilities are endless, and the game provides you with all the tools you need to make your creations come to life.

The game's sandbox-style gameplay is another standout feature, as it lets you explore a vast open world filled with obstacles, challenges, and hidden treasures. You can take on missions, gather resources, and compete with other players, all while discovering new areas and unlocking new parts to improve your vehicles.

But what truly sets Trailmakers apart is its attention to detail and its beautiful graphics. The game world is incredibly detailed, with lush environments, stunning lighting effects, and realistic physics that make your vehicles feel alive.

Overall, Trailmakers is an exceptional game that combines creativity, exploration, and action in a way that is truly unique. Whether you're a seasoned gamer or just starting out, this game is sure to keep you entertained for hours on end, and it definitely deserves a 10 out of 10 rating.

Trailmakers is everything I love about other vehicle building games with a better physics engine than any of them. 

I won't pretend it doesn't have some bugs here and there, with too many moving parts causing your vehicle to burst apart (and mirror mode is... definitely still a beta feature), but I have no other substantial gripes about it. There are few other games that I can pull 5 people together for, and it has kept us entertained for entire days.

Beyond the complexity limitations, this game lets me do just about anything I can think of and tests both my creativity and problem solving in a way I wish other games would. I suppose it's not for everyone, and that's why there are pre-built crafts to choose from if you're still learning or just plain don't want to build (you really should, though).

Overall, Trailmakers is by far one of the best sandbox experiences I have in my 200+ games on Steam, and that's not an overstatement. I love this game. If you find yourself unsatisfied with other vehicle builders, you probably will, too.

Trailmakers is my go to game. I prefer playing this to any other game.
It's quick to create something but takes a while to make something perfect. I've played Trailmakers for about 700 hours on my previous Steam profile. My previous account was sold together with my gaming laptop. Some creations take 6-12 hours to make as one can build something that's very complex, or you may decide on a shape of a creation but one that doesn't conform to physics and then it's a mission to get it to work properly. My Frankstein Asymmetrical Jet is an example of this.

There are an unlimited number of combinations one can use and it will be great when new parts are added with the upcoming DLC. Such a satisfying game. Those who become impatient with Trailmakers after purchasing it, should give it some time as there is so much enjoyment in seeing creations come to life.

I don't usually post negative reviews. But Trailmakers has really disappointed me.

Now, the game itself is a good idea. You go around the world, making vehicles, solving puzzles. But it's in the nuances of the game, and what the devs chose to do to it, that makes me upset.

First of all, it's really hard to make complicated things. There are only three logic gates, and they each take up a lot of space. 

Second of all, there is no 1x1x1 cube. I know this doesn't seem like a big deal, but when you have a 1 block space and want to fill it, you have to do some weird stuff with the other blocks to fill it, and that can take away from your design. The smallest block is 2x1.

And lastly, for a paid game, there are way too many DLCs. The game itself is $25.00, but you are only getting about 1/2 of the game. There is an oceans DLC for another $20, and the game is constantly trying to get you to buy that DLC. ON TOP OF THAT, there are so many other DLCs for blocks in the game, and when you try to download things from the workshop in-game, it tries to get you to buy those DLCs. With the Air Combat DLC coming out soon, it just isn't worth it to get this game. $25.00 for the amount of content you get is insanely overpriced, and the game just isn't that good. Don't buy this game unless you are prepared to spend lots of money on it.

TL;DR: This game is way overpriced with too many DLCs, and it isn't even that good.

absolute joy.
building is easy and intuitive, so that it never gets frustrating, but has enough depth to make complex stuff. Vehicles can be dead simple or carefully balanced and can be outfitted with all sorts of gizmos & gimmicks.

Currently there is enough content in singleplayer to tie you over for a lot of hours - if you enjoy racing your creations, or exploring the Campaign- & Sandbox-Maps. The game is pretty loose on it's structure, like many sandbox builders. Expect to 'make your own fun' with the options given for most the maps and modes.

The multiplayer needs some serious convenience upgrades in the server browser, and better stability, but it's wicked fun to have close tied races on the offroad tracks or harrowing aerial fights above the plane-carrier.

You can make fighter jets, blow up that 9 year-old who stole your build, break the sound barrier, make a sports car, design a tank, captain a battle ship, make a nuke, crash you PC, anything you like. I migrated here from the Scrap Mechanic community. Absolutely love the game. I came here because I love building aircraft (Something which Scrap Mechanic doesn't adequately support without mods) And found the perfect way to bring out my creativity. While I mainly build planes, helicopters, and the like, tanks, cars, boats, ships, really anything you can imagine, can be built. Trailmakers is by no means without its bugs and glitches but is surprisingly well rounded and the physics still surprise me to this day. I have somewhere around 2,800 hours in this game and there is no end in site for possible game play. I haven't even played the campaign yet! This game is very much alive and there is a constant stream of workshop content and an active multiplayer community which I have found to be mostly pleasant. Updates are good and fairly frequent from what I can tell. The multiplayer combat is (While a little wacky at times) surprisingly good and heaps of fun. I could spend all day dog fighting, and bombing, and avoiding AA guns, or maybe just chilling with some friends and building casually. The build system is well thought out and easy to use and get used too (Way easier than some games I've played) and gives you all the tools you need. There are plenty of parts and blocks and plenty of logic blocks. It can really support anything you want to do if you just spend enough time at it. A build can be as simple or complex as you like. There's nothing like the satisfaction you feel when you finally make a sonic boom, or make a plane that can cobra, or you find a new engineering principle to solve your problem. Honestly one of the best games I've played. Flashbulb, if you're reading this, amazing job! Can't wait for airborne, it is everything I ever wanted in this game!

I and my boy built about 900+ vehicles/contraptions and still counting. I mainly play this game to build something unique to my liking/imagination. The full support of controllers/game-pad is a big plus coz not many sandbox game support this (I tried other and usually disappointed with the controller support, then refund or ended up not playing em).
My boy really loves this game. He is playing (from the age of 3+yo until now he's 5+) this exclusively with a controller.. its easier to understand. 
We bought all the DLC to support the Dev and we love some (we don't really play the mission DLC like High Sea, we play that for the map, wind, waves.. not for the mission). 
I hope the developers keep making this game awesome and ...more block type please! Coz we are starting to get a bit bored with limitation now.. We really hope for local multiplayer at least  for 2 players on splitscreen. We need to make a good functioning walker/robot.  I hope theres a setting for the toughness option of the welding/the vehicles so it wont easily break with slight crash (or maybe make this an additional option for the seat block). Well... thats it!

[h1]I spent my time mostly racing and being fast, be it land air and sea. So this review is for those gear heads wanna be like me.[/h1]

[b]TLDR:[/b] I enjoyed the game, if I can make a mid rating I would have, unfortunately what makes this game bad is what limits its potential. It is still an enjoyable arcade creation/vehicle builder, but the hard parts limit, poor optimization and a few minor things is the reason this is a dislike. The game is still enjoyable and even satisfying to a point but the more I played the more glaring the bad stuff were, at least for me.

[h1]Cons: [/h1]
-A hard parts limit, I think its 600 ? not really a problem because there is a mod that can fix this and it's impossible to reach it if you just don't make any big creation. Though this problem will be apparent on the next con.

-Poor optimization, even before reaching 600 parts you can feel the lag, and I wasn't using any complicated equipment, just some pipes (for the body), 4 engines, 4 suspension, and the lag was just... bro why? Going fast you can have fps drops which is obviously bad for someone who likes going fast, where milliseconds decide if I die or just barely missing a rock/wall. For a game with graphics like this, it likes sending my GPU, a GTX 1650, to the moon and back i.e. fan go turbo mode (I know my GPU is not the best but come on it's not the worst).

-Clunky map physics. There are portions in all maps were "something" will destroy your vehicle. This is apparent to locations where there are changes in the ground/texture, especially the transition from asphalt to bridge. Going fast there will just destroy your entire creation. (a nitpick really)

-Simple destruction model. If you hit a wall or anything  at 100~ kph some of your vehicle should survive (especially the back part) but here your entire vehicle will just turn to ashes. not really a big problem there is a mod (strength mod i think?) that can make your parts beefier but it's not full proof, those parts can and will be destroyed anyway. (again a nitpick)

-No in depth editing/customization. I'm not talking about cosmetics, I mean the driving physics especially the wheels. You can't turn them off (e.g. you can't make RWD or FWD its only AWD baby) Not really a problem but having this would be nice. Ohh and the wheels just suck, not that their bad especially the normal ones (motorcycle wheel, spiked wheel), but you cant make them bigger or smaller. and the larger wheels (monster truck wheel and truck wheel?) are way too slow. Unless you dedicate 90% of the cars weight in engines you can barely hit 140kph. Which I do understand that irl larger wheels can't go fast but come one it's a game.

-Janky flying. I think this is not because of the physics, I think the physics are on point. The problem here is the control surfaces or rather how you can put control in them (hinges and the rotating rotor). This is hard to explain, but the flying physics is fine, there is just a junkiness in it that turns me off. Though this might be fixed in the upcoming DLC, and you don't need to buy the dlc to have the parts/fix so you'll be fine.

-Overall aesthetics, not really a problem. and its highly subjective. I like it actually but I also like some realistic looking parts. Even when those parts might exist due to how things connect it might be impossible to incorporate it to my design. I wish its possible to turn off some of the connecting parts. (but really just a nitpick)

-Not a true sandbox (at least for racing island) You can assume that the racing island is my favorite map but no, its my least favorite actually. Danger map(?) and treasure map was my favorite, why? because there are no starting lines, I hate the starting lines soo much, how it would initiate a race when you don't want to, and that I just want to go trough here fast man, but noooo go ahead put a giant f*cking wall where I want to go. Racing on this tracks are fine, except for some race tracks that lets you go to places where your vehicle will just break when going over certain areas, I'm looking at you Three bridges (the bump in between the first and second bridge, the second bridge, the turn right after the tunnel, the jump right before the third bridge, the third bridge entrance, and the third bridge exit, these portions right here are the bane of my existence), though I wish you can customize race tracks, especially the asphalt oval map I wish you can make 10 laps etc. and just not record it on the leader board or something. And the Rally mode (where you can do some racing missions) I wish we can go open world and explore there, but you can't you can only race some selected race tracks. 

-A not so in depth builder, It's not bad BUT it's missing a few things. For one a 1x1x1 block (the lego piece), I know you can fiddle around your creation so that you won't need a 1x1 block but I just want [b]it[/b] so i can put [b]it[/b] when I need [b]it[/b]. also I'm aware that a 6 sided pipe exist but its not aesthetically nice to look at. There is no custom pieces 7x5x2 idk what that would look like but it might solved lag.

-Can't cheat while other people are cheating, I don't mean it that way. What I mean here is that you can't make a times 5 power engine/jet engine, or a zero mass car. I know leaderboards exist so yeah you can't cheat but come one. There are people who reach 00:00:000 in the leader boards how are they still there without cheating? Again a nitpick, I don't really care about the leaderboards, but I would like to know what a zero mass car/lighter vehicle would feel like driving around XD or even have a x10 power engine XD.

-Car class won't matter anyway, why put car classes when there's only one leader board anyway? doesn't matter if your rocking a 1 core vehicle or a 666 core monster you'll be facing each other in the leaderboards. Again just a nitpick, I don't care about leader boards, but... why though? 

[h1]Pros: [/h1]
-Game is simple and arcady, You don't need to create your engine, suspension unit, and you don't need to connect the fuel tanks to the engine with a fuel line. just drag and drop the necessary things and boom you have a vehicle.

-Aesthetics. (I know subjective) but it looks like a Lego and that is good enough for me.

-Basic computing stuffs, logic gates, speedometer, altimeter etc. you can create a complex machine with this.

-Physics are on point, I'm not saying realistic, but it feels right when you are going fast

-Downforce done right. I love the feel of the vehicle when you put enough (and even too much) downforce on your vehicle, it be well planted and you can corner like a beast. Main problem here is putting too much will fully compress your suspension so a no suspension vehicle can work, BUT you can't off road and asphalt is not cheap in this game, so finding a right mix as well as center of downforce is important if you're going of road and you MUST go off road, it's not a choice.

-Creativity, I've made an F1 car with an additional jet engine that only activates upon reaching a specific speed, and a working DRS that actually increases my top speed by 20kph ( it automatically activates as well) and I love how it basically turns the vehicle into a uncontrollable mess with the reduction in downforce BUT ANYTHING FOR MORE SPEED BABY!!!

-The game is very cheap and you don't need any of the DLCs, to enjoy the parts (aside from cosmetics dlc which you don't need) The high seas add a few hours of gameplay (though very tedious and boring) and the upcoming dlc actually has a story. Which I don't really care but it's good to have.

[h1]Conclusion: [/h1]
The game is a fun arcade sandbox, you can have fun with this and for it's price I say it's worth it. This game is not really for a gearhead like me. But the game has it's merits, It has a relaxing campaign while I only spent a few hours on the campaign it actually requires you to think. It has a nice atmosphere and building mechanic that is simple and it works.

I absolutely love it, it has become one of my favorites. The word "Unique" is the definition of playing through this wonderful game and the experience I have had so far is astounding. Though You are missing the 1x1s it would be a very pleasing update to see added.
Edit: You should also allow more complexity with the machines I often hit the limit with my projects.

This game is so fun and innovative 10/10

Trailmakers is a fantastic game that offers players a unique sandbox experience, where you get to design, build, and race your own vehicles in an open-world environment. From the very start, the game immerses you in a world of creativity and endless possibilities, allowing you to create anything you can imagine using an intuitive building system.

One of the things I loved about Trailmakers is how easy it is to get started. The game has a very user-friendly interface that makes building and designing vehicles a breeze, even for those who have no experience in this genre. Whether you want to build a car, a plane, or a helicopter, Trailmakers gives you all the tools you need to create your own unique vehicle from scratch.

But what really sets Trailmakers apart from other games is its emphasis on exploration and adventure. The game worlds are big, with a vast array of different environments to explore, from mountains and deserts to forests and oceans. And with a variety of challenges and objectives to complete, there's always something new and exciting to discover.

Trailmakers also offers a variety of gamemodes, from a survival-style exploration campaign, to simple sandbox and thrilling race chanllenges.

The game's graphics are also worth mentioning, as they are simply stunning. The artstyle is simply stunning, and the attention to detail is evident.

Overall, I highly recommend Trailmakers to anyone who loves sandbox games, creative building, and exploration. With its intuitive building system, gorgeous graphics, and endless possibilities, this game is sure to provide hours of fun and entertainment. So why not jump in and start building your dream vehicle today?

Not bad, but not great either, get it on sale if you want a game where you can build some planes and heli's without the need for mods, but beware that they are kinda janky and if you want anything half decent you need to use tricks and glitches anyway, so you might as well just do that with mods in a building game you already own ğŸ¤·â€â™‚ï¸

Im only recommending because i did get a decent amount of hours with doing just that, making some planes & heli's, but honestly everything else kinda sucks & most building games run circles around this one, see the below lists. I really tried to come up with more Pro's (because i certainly don't dislike the game) but idk, if i'm honest and compare this to other games in the genre then Trailmakers is mediocre at best.

Pro's:
- Flying stuffs (also submarine stuffs, but that's bscly the same thing)
- More wedges/sloped blocks compared to most grid-based building games

Con's:
- Cant build onto the world (massive oversight really cutting down on the amount of things to do)
- You are pretty limited by build complexity (yea okay you can get a mod, but then the game just struggles to stay alive)
- Destruction mostly just seems to be random (crash into a wall can be losing a single part or entire vehicle shattering)
- After 4 years of people complaining about it half the wheels still bug into the ground
- After 4 years of requests we still don't have a way to visualize center of mass/lift/thrust/drag/etc so you end up just guessing together your planes/heli's/boats/etc trough trail and error, which is honestly ridiculous when you consider that air & water 'physics' are this games biggest selling point.
- Development for the base game has apparently stopped?? new building parts are exclusive to paid DLC now, the developer didn't take the hint when last DLC like that got a poor review score i guess.

Thread carefully, buy this in a sale if you see something you like, have some fun, then go back/move on to a better building game.

Needs a serious revamp in terms of coding. Can be very infuriating to work with when it comes to figuring out what's wrong with your vehicle and why it won't work, and sometimes the physics feel like they're coded by a crackhead. That said, this game manages to be among my top played regardless, there is such a large amount of customization of your vehicles, your character is so neutral you barely even notice how uncustomizable they are, and the vehicles themselves have so many options to choose from. You can make a mecha, a biplane, a submarine, a freakin mechanical boy riding a giant bicycle, an accurate recreations of your favorite WW2 or Star Wars vehicle, the choices are yours, assuming you can work your way through the mazes of weird problems the game throws at you.

I've gone back and forth on this game, but ultimately, the inability to rebind basic controls and some hardcoded keys has killed my interest.

The straw that broke the camel's back was when I went to revisit the game today and tried to assign "F" to control one of my blocks and was told that that key couldn't be assigned.

Newer review: [strike]I made time to go back and try Trailmakers again.  I'm enjoying the campaign mode a lot, but don't know how much I'll get out of the other modes.

In any case, my original review was no longer accurate, and I can now recommend this game.  My biggest complaint now is the lack of keybinding.[/strike]

Original review: [strike]TL;DR: I'd wait until the devs get a few more patches in.

Multiple crashes on startup killed not only the game, but my actual Steam client. Disabling the Steam overlay allowed the game to continue past the crash point, but I'm not sure that I want to try to continue playing a game that has that kind of bad interaction with Steam itself.

I looked into contacting the developers for help and they seemed like they would have been responsive, but their discord channel has a mandatory wait time before you post and I'm not feeling very patient with a game this hostile to the platform it lives on.

My hope is to possibly try it again after a few updates to see if things have improved, but I don't want it sitting in my library between now and then.  Refund requested.[/strike]

I never heard about this game until i saw it on steam and decided to give it a try.

[h1] What is the game's idea? [/h1]

The game gives you the opportunity to build your own vehicle, putting on the tweaks you want, the features you wish and the design you are dreaming about.
it will make your dream vehicle come true!

[h1] What game modes does the game offer?[/h1]

The game offers you a campaign mode but i didn't try it yet ( i will update when i do) and a sandbox (creative mode)

For the multiplayer, you can basically do everything you do in single player but with a friend
Help them building their own car, race with them , play story , and have fun.

[h1] Do I need to buy the DLCs to enjoy the game? [/h1]

No, you don't have to!
The game offers you most of the parts you would use to build the car (almost all of them)
it won't destroy your experience if you didn't buy the DLC that unlocks the rest!

Also , there are some DLCs for more customization (Buy them if you just want to look more fancy)

[h1] Ugh the game is so hard to understand! [/h1]

Welp, always check the guides in steam and the tutorial videos. it would help you understand physics and make you build your vehicle better!

Hope you all, Enjoy that amazing game <3

I can recommend it if you're after a simpler and easier vehicle builder, it has "everything" you would expect: logic, water, aero, multiplayer, races. It's good for cars, planes, boats all that stuff, but the block building system makes it rather unfeasible to make replicas of real life vehicles.

However for anyone hoping to make big or advanced projects in this game, i strongly advise against it. It can get pretty laggy or glitchy with high amounts of blocks and the physics aren't really that great for anything complex. The logic is rather simplified, it's binary and there's a rather limited amount of components to use.

Water physics are okay, just like any other building game, place a pontoon and bam your creation magically floats on the water. The aerodynamics don't make sense most of the time, but what can you do about it, they exist and are a thing.
 
The worlds are quite small for such a game (if you don't count the almost endless water surrounding them), there are only 2 of them (not counting the campaign and racing maps).

There are a lot of graphic settings in-game, but there are practically no general/standard settings, you can't even change the language, framerate, controls, nothing...

And the devs are in my opinion the worst out of any sandbox game, instead of making normal content updates for what i consider an unfinished game, they make mediocre dlcs with content that should be in the base game. 

The community or as i call it "blind fanbase" is pretty rough too, they support all their controversial decisions and will cancel you if you disagree, it's almost like twitter.
Very interesting while playing, you get to learn new things, you get make your own ideas, and it's just so fun! Highly Recommend.

One of the Best Games Ever Made. 

I payed something like Â£2 for this game on sale. It is without a doubt one of the best games I have ever played in my life, (and I've played a lot of games). 

If you want a brief description of this. It is a  physics based puzzle-solving game where you must create and operate the right vehicle in order to progress. 

If you have played Banjo Kazooie: Nuts and Bolts, Trailmakers basically follows the same exact formula. If you liked N&B, you will like this. To compare this game to BK:N&B, Trailmakers places much more emphasis on the gameplay and the variety of vehicles, as well as the mechanics. Whereas N&B has more personality with characters and comedy aspects. Trailmakers is essentially a serious/complex version of BK:N&B. But to those who have played one and not the other. Both are worth trying out. 

One complaint I do have is how hard and frustrating it can be to get to grips with the flying portions of the game. creating a flying vehicle that functions how you expect it to is quite difficult. It is something that may grate on you over time, as to fly properly, you require pieces of machinery that are not easy to obtain. I would suggest watching a guide on how to do this decently with minimal parts of machinery (instead of annoying yourself with trial and error like I did). 

Overall, this is a great game. Easily one of my favourite games ever, due to its variety and the way it has held my interest far longer than most games I have played lately. It's not an easy game, so if you're up for a challenge, this will provide one.

What can I say that hasn't already been said? I played a bunch on Game pass for PC before i finally got it here on Steam. For 6 bucks, no less. What a steal! 

Pros:

Fantastic building system, IMO. Either that, or I've gotten (it's a word, I checked) so used to it that playing other, similar games don't feel right at times lol. 

Huge maps to roam and create freely in. 5, if I'm not mistaken. 

2 Campaign maps, tailored to teach you the basic of building and the basics of racing inside Trailmakers. Stranded in Space - adapt your creation to collect all the parts and get off the rock you crashed on. Rally - Race on various courses, increasing in difficulty, also adapting your vehicle to beat time challenges. - Both huge and open. 

A newly released map called High Seas. (DLC, but worth.) Add all of the goodness of a sandbox and now add realistic wind physics to already realistic water physics, and voila. There's a lot of fun to be had there, especially with a bunch of parts being added, too. The sails being a prime example. 

2 actual sandbox maps: Treasure Island - for doing treasure hunts and whatnot. Danger zone - Has all sorts of contraptions and prebuilt structures to do various amounts of destruction and even has CARBALL. (Rocket League, here's looking at you) Pretty sure the workshop has faithful recreations of actual cars and arenas from Rocket League, as well. Which brings me to another pro.

The mods! This speaks for itself. go check the workshop. lol

And now for the

Cons:

The building system is limited to x,y,z vertices. But, aren't most games of a similar vein? Not that big of a deal, imo.

On rare occasions, there are some weird glitches that can happen. Your tire clipping an invisible piece of the ground, sending your creation flying off into the sunset or just obliterated into actual smithereens. Haha, smithereens. What a word. Anyway..

Speaking of glitches, there are a few that are actually helpful and used a lot in the community. See Youtubers and such for that. 

Lastly for cons, while there are a good number of parts, a builder junkie like myself could always use more. Specifically a few that, imo, should already be in game. different sizes, etc, as well. Annnd, more paint options. lol Love me some aesthetics. 

Thanks for coming to my TE- ah, whatever.

I've only completed the singleplayer so far, so this review is wrt. that only. I was recommended this game by someone who knew I was working on a vehicle building game myself, so this is mainly my interpretation of the design choices as I see them fitting into the vehicle builder genre.
First of all, all the vehicles you can come up with in this game feel excellent, its very hard to make a vehicle that doesn't feel good, with the exception of helicopters, but that's something of an unsolved problem genre-wide. The vehicle building UX is also great, though some desirable hotkeys are missing, it lends itself very well to either mouse or keyboard control. It seems like it would work perfectly with a controller too.
The open world singleplayer where you collect blueprints is a great idea; it does a good job of tempting you to try things that maybe you aren't supposed to be able to yet. For example I got one of the scraps with a fixed wing vehicle that looks like it was definitely intended to be helicopter-only. I also had a great time picking up Volatile scraps from my plane and flying them through recovery drones without landing. My only complaints about this mode is the "barriers" (eg between land, sea, sub, and air vehicles being accessible), while present, don't have much gameplay lead-in. I found the tractor beam much later than I believe I was supposed to. I also spent a ton of time wondering when I'd finally get an air propulsion part when I already had tons of wings. I guess you could say the sequencing is prone to players getting "lost". I think this could be addressed with an Outer Wilds style "clues" system, which could also prevent players from feeling like they are finding a ton of scraps they don't care about, by giving them the option to hunt down the ones they want first.

14.12.2022 - Nearly 2000 hours played

Aight, re-re-review time...

Trailmakers despite it's apparent simplicity is the best construction game I know in terms of visuals (Believe me, I have been looking for a while), though most of these visuals are achieved with a glitch that lets you overlap several blocks. This glitch unfortunately has it's limits and often breaks since it's unintended, meaning usually several hours are spent fighting with the game engine to finally achieve a desirable result.
The last statement is not only applicable to said glitch though, it is applicable to many situations. No creation with more than 10 mechanical blocks is finished without having to fight against the game engine.

The simplicity of the building while useful for a starting player, is a double edged knife for veteran players. The locked grid makes building easy, but it badly limits what shapes you can create. Since there are only so many sizes of blocks most of the time to create a specific shape it's almost required for players to use the above mentioned glitch to create these shapes. The problem is that mechanical blocks which are necessary to do it cost 5 complexity, compared to normal blocks only consuming 1 per piece. That combined with the fact you can only have 700 complexity worth of parts in one creation means you are forced into a choice of "should I make this shape accurate or should I make it janky and blocky to save on complexity to finish the rest of the creation". 
The main reason this limit exists is because of the weak hardware that console users are running, not that the game engine can't handle far more complexity. While this is completely understandable, the critical lack of block shapes is not excusable. It's not rare to see weird gaps or bumps in creations, especially in corners. For large creations details have to be sacrificed for the creation to even be able to exist. This often causes large creations to look extremely bland.
Other things of note are the two boring and repetitive campaigns (Mostly redeemed in 1.6), extremely small maps, as well as the lack of proper coloring options, there only being ~12 colors available.

There is also a big problem in communication between the developers. While they do listen to the community and take their concerns and ideas into mind, they often add whatever they feel is needed in the game, not what the game actually needs.
A majority of the playerbase complains of the same few issues, yet the development is focused on new content instead of fixing what is critically broken.
We are at the point where most of the active community isn't even bothered to ask for these problems to be fixed, and instead they are passive-aggressively joked about.

A lot of the new features added to the game are also super half-baked on release, often missing features one would expect should be there.
Examples are:
- Mirror mode | Still unfinished "beta" feature after 3 updates. Only functions if both sides of the creation are symmetrical, only works in one axis, doesn't even work properly sometimes.
- Grip block | Grip value is not adjustable, easily breaks on impact meaning almost useless in walker feet.
- Decals | You can't resize height and width individually, all decals are digital instead of vectors (meaning you can see the pixels on decals if they are large enough), you cannot change the texture on decals like you can on blocks, there is a limit of 1 decal per block and there is no option to clone a decal onto two sides of a block, meaning you can't apply decals to both sides of a 1 block wide tailfin.
- Lights | You cannot change the color of lights. The game can display different colored lights, but you cannot change it.
- Noteblocks (sound blocks) | Only a few sounds are available, there is no controller for noteblocks, each note needs to be timed and pitched individually, meaning music is extremely difficult to make.
- Logic | Signal falloff, different gate types, remote detection, player tracking, conical raycasts, mouse position tracker (left/right click added in 1.6 as inputs), rotation sensor, etc. etc. (This could go on for a WHILE)
- Magnet (now "tractorbeam") | After 1.4 rework magnet engines, railguns, and maglev trains all broke. Magnet turned from short range, short radius, powerful grabbing device into medium range, super wide radius, unstable grabbing device.
- Blocks | Tons of block shapes you would expect are missing, meaning there are tons of inter-connectivity and smoothness issues.
- Sails | Sails simply do not function like sails, they act like gigantic wing panels.
- Spoiler/Wings | The spoiler block is both lighter and provides more lift than the dedicated wing block? + Big wing provides LESS lift than two small wings that take up the same area.
- Mechanical blocks | When given a signal that is less than 100%, some mechanical blocks adjust the maximum angle, while others adjust their current movement speed. You cannot choose between which, or do both at the same time.
- Ski | Ski only works if perfectly level with ground
- Drag | Some blocks do not have drag, while others do. There is no consistency.
- Wheels | Tire pressure is not adjustable, meaning most wheels sink into the ground when just a small amount of weight is applied. Wheels being offset with the ground on their spinning axis causes shadow forces that move the creation around. In other words, creations with tilted wheels move forwards/backwards uncontrollably at all times.

That's not to mention the overpriced DLCs that the developers have been forced to push out, since not enough people are buying the game due to the bad reputation it gets for the gigantic amount of frustrating bugs, some of which still exist despite them being known for years.
The worst one by far is the hat DLC, adding about 6 totally random looking hats and costing a whopping 4â‚¬ which is the same amount as the skin packs and decal packs which actually add something worth the price to the game.
Then there is the High seas DLC... 10â‚¬ for a map that is 80% ocean (oceans already exist on all sandbox maps) with the only special thing about it being waves and weather effects + wind. These are only available on the DLC map, and not on any others. Horrible choice.
These should be optional features that can be enabled on any map as long as you own the DLC.
The new parts included in the DLC alone are not worth the 10â‚¬ price tag. The map does not make up for the rest of the price.


All in all, I am happy with the game, though I am very worried for it's future. If these years old bugs that are constantly making people angry at the game aren't fixed, it will not have a long lifespan left. If you buy the game now, just be aware that it may only have a few more years before it kicks the bucket. 
Oh and expect to spend more money on future DLCs just to be able to access most of the new content KEKL

Edit: 
I got this game with my friend with the intention of beating the campaign with him, and had been really looking forward to it as I had just finished playing a multiplayer scrap mechanic run and really enjoyed it. 

 had known about this game for a long time and really liked it conceptually, so when I finally got my hands on it I was really disappointed. From an outside perspective watching videos and seeing the building I thought it looked really nice and satisfying, but the camera was very frustrating to operate and I was really let down. Then once I hopped in a game with my friend I was very disappointed with the generic "I crashed my ship now I need a new one to escape!" story that I had seen with so many other games, including scrap mechanic. Then when I finally built a car and was driving around I was really disappointed to see the only objective be to grab and push boxes to a spot on the map.

If you are a creative with a keenness to adventure, you will certainly enjoy this game! The campaign has you crash landed in some unknown planet. Your mission is to collect as many parts, as best you can, to build a spaceship and secure a ride back home. For the most part, the physics in the game provide a smooth experience when building, testing, or just cruising around the maps. A couple bugs I have ran into in the campaign alone are, one a bug where if you travel too fast across certain sections of land, your vehicle will spontaneously combust, and two, if you have two or more suspension coils next to each other, they have a tendency to create a bunch of energy and jolt your vehicle in any and all directions. The second bug is easily avoidable, so not a big deal. Certainly doesn't take away from the fun, as you can rebuild your models, and respawn with little to no penalties (in survival your objective will reset if you die). There are plenty of other perks to the game as well, but why would you spend all your time reading this when you could experience it in-game!?

I have one major gripe with Trailmakers, and that's the tractor beam thrust glitch. 

If you don't pick up whatever item you're trying to grab PERFECTLY CENTER, a huge plume of smoke starts emitting and creates a massive thrust on the vehicle. This makes picking up items in High Seas via helicopter unfathomably frustrating. You've just spent five minutes fighting hurricane force winds to line up the shot, you get a slightly imperfect capture and suddenly you are rolling or spinning out of control. From a physics sim POV, this is a pretty game-ending glitch for me.

I've dumped countless hours in this game, usually I have nothing but positive things to say about it, but this glitch, along with many other small ones really make it feel cheap compared to other physics sims. The High Seas expansion was the best thing to happen to this game but the devs need to do some major house-keeping fixing bugs, or its all for nothing. 

For instance, when making chains of mechanical components, errors tend to compound until they exeed the limits of the components and cause breaks or unwanted behavior. If you make a literal chain of trailer hinges and pipes for example, after about 10 links, the physics engine starts to choke and the components begin to vibrate and sometimes disassemble.  Same with multiple combining hinges to servos, things start breaking for no reason.

Overall a good game that keeps bringing me back, but I've reached the point where I am trying to beat the physics engine, and not the obstacles of the game itself.

This game is good if you are not interested in competitive play. Everything is run server side which means any competitive play comes down to who has least ping. The extremely limited logic system means anything more advanced than altitude hold or gun stabilization is nigh impossible since everything is either on or off. Fly by wire systems for high agility aircrafts or basic PID systems are impossible. Updates are sparse and nowadays only add cosmetics and nothing else. 

tldr. Don't play for too long or look too deep or play competitively.

I had to think a while before I recommended this game or not, the concept is wonderful, and the game has potential, but there are some aspects of the physics simulation that really ruined it for me. for instance, a pontoon style water craft I attempted would immediately flip end over end as soon as power was applied in spite of the buoyant pieces that should have prevented that. A motorcylce design I attempted had a similar issue where it would flip forward as soon as you applied power, as if the torque on the front wheel was causing the entire vehicle to lever over the front, and putting extra weight on the back had no effect.

You could certainly learn the quirks of the physics and incorporate them into your designs, but they are unintuitive to someone wanting to play engineer.

If you like Scrap Mechanic, you should really enjoy Trailmakers. It has much better physics than SM and the Stranded and High Seas modes give you challenges and goals to work toward. It gets a lot right, but does have its flaws. For example, the destructive physics, while loads of fun, are pretty unforgiving. It's too easy to destroy your vehicle even at slow speeds. Invisible environment edges randomly snag and smash vehicles. Connecting parts is much easier than in SM, but you can't recursively examine connected parts at a glance like you can in SM. Overall, despite it's flaws, it's a fantastic game for creating and perfecting contraptions.

Its no Robocraft replacement, the game is not made to be a PVP game, some PVP elements are there but no actual players or large server to host them, you can make complicated builds and show them off to your friends but that's about it when it comes to playing with other people, I didn't bother with the single player campaign you can see other reviews.

Overall, this game is just OK, for me. The build controls are wonky, as well as the camera. The depth in the build screen is frustrating. When you take a piece off of one of your vehicles when looking at it from the front or back, it will suddenly end up on the other side of the vehicle. Lining up pieces is just frustrating. Depth perception within the build screen is all messed up, it is like building with one eye open. It is difficult to line up pieces with the popup menus, I accidentally push menu buttons constantly while building. You can guide pieces with WASD, but it is difficult because the direction the pieces move is based on where your camera is pointing in the build screen. The camera controls in this game are odd. While driving, flying, etc., if you want a free floating camera you need to hold down the right mouse button... It would be better in my opinion if you could just completely control the direction of the camera with the mouse. Otherwise, it is a following camera that is stuck to the rear of your vehicle. The camera moves with you, but it is sluggish at best. You can not control the brightness in this game and you can not map your mouse and keyboard controls for this game. Building in direct "sunlight" is impossible. You can not see where to line up your pieces. I have had to adjust the color of my pieces so I am able to see what I am doing. The same goes for building in the dark, too dark to see. I have had several bugs as well with the explosive power cores not resetting after an attempt to gather them. The explosive power cores will float in mid air, and behave just like the NPC flying mob that drops coins when you approach them with your vehicle. You then will have to chase the power core until it drops out of the sky. A very annoying bug. Flying in this game is a hassle, either with a plane or a helicopter, the physics are weird. I am not even going to get into that... If these problems were to be addressed I would highly enjoy this game. But these little annoyances are adding up, and I am ready to be done before I finish the campaign.

This game is really a love hate relationship, I wish i could love this game, I wish I could be optimistic about this game, I'll be very harsh here, don't let this deceive you to not buy the game, im pointing out the 3 main problems with the game, but it's still VERY good. Let's start with:

1. Bugs/glitches

This is a physics game, so it is expected to have bugs, but it's not the bugs that are the problem, it's the developers not caring about those bugs, sure they made a reddit post asking for bugs, yet they fixed only a few but they claim the game is finished(?) while it has even a high amount of bugs for a physics game, they fixed a few bugs, but with new updates they're adding more bugs than they fix, so lets get to the next part:

2. Extremely low quality dlc's (half-assed dlc's/updates just for quick bucks)

I'm fine with the game having dlc's, even 6 dlc's, but the quality of those dlc's, or even quantity of stuff you get is the issue, with the new update (decals) it comes with 2 dlc's, they're cheap, but having to pay for over half of the update which you get only a few free things is outrageous, if it continues like this, then the people who don't buy dlc's are gonna have very little new content from updates, and let's talk about the high seas dlc, some may like it while some don't, it's subjective but I don't like it, I feel like the devs half-assed the dlc, you start like a sandbox with all the parts already, and same as stranded in space you just go collecting different shaped things (rocks?) to the salvage things, they did a weird thing between sandbox and campaign, I don't like it, both parts were poorly executed.

3. Devs barely listen to the community

So many good suggestions go to the reddit and trello, yet almost nothing good the community wants is actually implemented, more offensive armament for more fun in multiplayer? nope. laser pointers? nah. custom spawn points? never. building together? not happening. better shield mechanics? also no. propellers powered by engines? you know it, hell no.

Now that's a lot of cons, but nonetheless with all the bugs, half-assed updates/dlc's, devs almost ignoring the community suggestions, terribly executed ideas, i still can't help but to play this game, it is playable and i love the creativity you can do here, it's still VERY fun, If you love creativity/building games, BUY IT, you won't regret it, I played it for so much and it is the best game I've played, next to Warthunder that is, but i recommend it.


If some of these issues were fixed, i could (and would) put in 3,000 hours to this game.


TLDR:  half-assed updates/dlc's, developers don't listen to community, terribly executed ideas, but still immensely fun nonetheless, you can do so much here, if you like building, BUY IT, you won't regret buying it.

TL;DR: It's alright, the game's biggest blessing AND curse is that it's 100000% a sandbox. I'd almost give it a NO just for the glitches and jankiness.

The campaign is "here's a world full of stuff, find stuff to make stuff to get access to more stuff" and doesn't really care if you make a lopsided janky doodadmobile to wiggle a part out of place so you can get better access to it with something that works better, or slapping a stick on the end of a plane so you can whack a scrap part off a tower of rocks as you zip by. No rules or anything, so it's just a matter of aimlessly wandering from part to part until you've found everything and you get to watch a low-res cutscene.
Basically the goal here is getting parts to get more parts so you can get more parts until you have them all.
Also, a lot of the parts aren't particularly useful, like racing tires when there's no roads, most of the engines when you can get the best one pretty easily, guns when there's no enemies, plane parts when helicopters are needed 100x more for carrying cargo, etc.

The sandbox modes are all summarized as "here, you have everything, go diddle around the map until you get bored, and a lot of "make your own fun" stuff like an arena that you and another player could maybe fight in, or a big slapping piston thing that smashes your vehicle because ???, or little challenges you can do to earn coins used to buy cosmetic stuff.

The other modes are race modes, where you're locked down to a limited number of parts and have to do little races using what little you've got, or you can spend those cosmetic coins to unlock some of the parts back for aerodynamics or whatever, but honestly you're just racing to earn parts you probably already got in the campaign so you can do better races and unlock of your parts again, but the racing mode is held back a bit by how janky the physics are in the game, and especially by the lack of a center of mass visibility toggle.

Overall, I guess the best I can say is that the game's a cool sandbox, but that's really all it is, IMO. Wouldn't recommend it at full price, and probably wouldn't recommend buying any of the DLC (the High Seas DLC is just another sandbox, but with more water and wind physics, and some ship parts you probably wont use outside the mode.)

IÂ´m a big fan of physics building games and really want to love this one, but sadly I canÂ´t.

Once you get to a point were youÂ´re building serious stuff the lack of optimisation, glitches and janky buiding and physics just sucks all the fun out. It feels halfassed. In a good physics sandbox every new part feels like a real present and you canÂ´t wait to try what you can do with it, in this game it just feels like youÂ´re fighting the physics to get it to work halfway decent. It gets very old after a few hours when literally everything new you build that isnÂ´t a basic car or boat is a wonky mess to use. The build menu, which is pretty important in a game like this, is a PITA with inconsistent snap, glitchy mirror mode and bugged error markers.

What seals the deal for me is that instead of some optimisation, quality of life improvements and a bit of love for the game, we get stale microtransactions that should have been unlockables.

This is a great game, for building/testing/racing. There are acceptable physics problems such as. Tires do not deflect but rather "sink" in to the ground, they will pop/bob back (deflect back). Clipping exists yet it may not always, you will just have to test the Structure/vehicle. servo stacking (the only way bionic league can be fun). 

There is quit a lot shapes, vehicles, and mechanisms you can make with just blocks (objects inside a six sided cube/rectangle, size dependent)! You can must of your fantastical designs. For all that, the meta for fast cars, boats, and aircraft is well established (it dose variate between the three).    

The power system (showing how much power a propulsion-tech/motor has) is odd and not fallowed though for all systems, but it would be hard to implement a accurate system in for such a creative game.

Now in to the negatives. Trailmakers is a fun game to even when avoiding the, moderately excepted exploits/glitches. The game braking/stopping glitches can seen when stressing the systems, other wise the game runs fine.

There are two main glitches, the inverted hover-pad simulated ground proximity engine (known as the ufo engine or hover-pad glitch) and the detachable aerodynamics/drag (known as the 0-drag glitch).

Some failing's of the game are the spoiler's (rear wing), aerodynamic display (at the low-drag/slippery end), number accuracy (decimal places), and the two cosmetic blocks that fall out of the fair range.
The in-game rear-wing (spoiler) gains it's activeness from the open space (the eight 1x1x1-cubes) above it's surface, not the front or rear section. 
The aerodynamic display is based off the color and speed of on coming arrows, at low drag (green in color) the arrows are moving at speed with only slight variation. 
The accuracy is only up to one decimal place (10th's), advanced settings for this would be nice. 
The 1x2-Chrome-bumper and 1x2- chrome-bumper-detail have three plains of contact with at least one point, this with no drag allows increased size without the penalty of drag.
Very fun and somewhat educational. Had me looking up how planes and helicopters work to be able to make them in game, as well as suspension systems. Highly recommend it.

Awesome game, built incredibly well and with tons of attention to detail. 

--( MECHANICS )--
In general, it's incredibly put together while also not being too complex. It easily appeals to players both looking for a simple experience to drive around cars and pilot planes, along with people looking for a way to express their creativity through the amazing building mechanics the game has to offer.

--( GENERAL QUALITY )--
The quality is definitely a point worth making. The game is really high quality for the price tag, with really accurate physics (bugs do still happen on occasion) along with good quality graphics that make it both a good game to play and a good game to enjoy the occasionally breathtaking views (although I rarely do that).

--( ENTERTAINMENT )--
The game is generally fun in most cases. Honestly, whether you want to build, drive, or just chill out with friends the game has these capabilities easily accessed. The tutorial effectively and quickly teaches base mechanics, the workshop allows people to gather both inspiration and fun vehicles to drive and test out, the campaign allows a way to challenge players to think like an engineer and solve problems to get the next piece of the spaceship or a new item to use for transport, and the ability to host servers and configure the settings to your liking makes it easy to set up a way to play with friends and other players alike.

--( CONCLUSION )--
In all ways, this game is built incredibly well and made with multiple kinds of players in mind - whether it be competitive players racing to get the best score on Race island, creative players working to build amazing creations to share with the world, players looking to get inspiration and entertainment from other's creativity, players looking for every Easter egg and looking to complete every achievement for a 100% completion of the game, and more put in this incredibly amazing game that appeals to more than just players with an engineering mindset.

To start off, there is so much that is great with this game. The building process is easy to learn and the amount of freedom with keybinds makes creations very fun to drive. The game also has a great style and mechs look great. The physics is great in this game and makes it so satisfying transitioning from land to sea to the air. By far my favorite thing about this game is being able to live your best Transformer life. Switching between vehicles looks so great and feels so sick. If you're a creative and love sharing/interacting with a community then you'll have a great time with this game.

Now to get into my gripes with the game. I loved the building in the game but it felt a little aimless. For me I am not that big on building things just to show others. There is a 'story' mode that gives you objectives to achieve but the challenges weren't all that hard. You can pretty much collect every scrap ball if you make a drone. There are some small physics issues that I have found but those are not game ending. 

Overall the game has a great look and feel but I kind of wish there was more to do in it.

it's a good game, simple to understand, and easy to enjoy for hours at a time.

- the only downside i can see is the " currently " somewhat limited content.

you can " currently " choose between ( sandbox mode ), ( race mode ), ( main game mode ), and the newly added ( water world mode ). 

these modes themselves are all fun in their own ways, but between them all, the total amount of things you can " currently " do is still limited enough to get repetitive fairly quickly. - there are only so many balls and cubes you can gather before getting bored of gathering balls and cubes.

that said, i still recommend at least giving this game a try, who knows, you may just find yourself enjoying it.

1. Its fun to play the multiplayer.
2. Singleplayer story is okay.
3. Crashes very often even years after release (1-3 times a day).
4. Performance on multiplayer is bad (Very much laggs, low FPS and more).
5. You disconnect for no reason from servers all the time (2-9 times a day).
6. Physics are bad programmed, buggy and not very realistic.
7. WAY TO LESS blocks for building so you cant be that creative at all.
8. Some bugs are known since years and they dont get fixed. Instead they release new 
    blocks which are 99% useless and you have to pay for it. If you want more realistic water 
    physics you have to pay because they made new water physics 
    but only for one exclusive map and all other maps with water still have the old physics. And 
    the new physics only has waves nothing more is new on the new water.

9. Idk why but i love this game even if it makes me hate it.

Alright so, i do enjoy this game.. it is fun and generally a good way to waste time if your someone who likes games similar to scrap mechanic. However, i will not recommend this game due to its horrendous server stability. Ive got fairly good net (2mbs)  and this game will give me server connection issues and kick me off lobbies left and right. and God forbid this happens too often or you try to connect right after getting knocked off. the game will go nuclear and crash. And im sorry, your not gonna stick around and play this game for long if your not doing multiplayer as thats where the fun is, mostly.

And might i add, i always check for file integrity, i dont run mods that can crash the game, most if not all my creations are fairly basic. my specs are well above the mark for playing this game. Simply put, the issues im having are all server side. this may never happen to you, and if not then hey awesome. but i know im not alone.

It's decent. Snapping the vehicles together works well, and the vehicle building has a good balance of simplicity vs creative freedom. That being said, I'm not feeling super into it, and the reason for that is the campaign. It's open world, without a lot of direction, which I love, but the challenges are too easy imo. You basically collect these metorites, which are in hard to reach places, but you can clearly see right from the get go how each is meant to be reached. "oh I need to make my car taller", "I need to make it faster to jump that gap", etc. Most of the gamplay is just going through the motions to snap together what you already know will work.
This game is really fun and brings out the creativity within you.
I love it! I love the building the flying and all the other things that come with this game. I highly recommend this.
This game is the best game ever. I very well love the stranded in space campaign.
the game is really fun but for some reason it says my profile is ofline and i cant download blue prints from the wrokshop wich really sucks

Now don't get me wrong the game is fun to MAKE things but not to USE them. My only complaint that I can think of as of writing this is the they don't have a 1x1x1 block, that's really my only building complaint. The big reason why I give this game a negative review is that using your creation is a pain in the a**. If you want to make anything that shoots and is on a turret the controls are a nightmare. The Dev's never added a mouse control to the game so you'll have to get by with mapping the turret controls to weird places like... Left and right would be mapped to Q and E then up and down would be mapped to X and C or something along those lines, truly a pain in the a**. Another small thing that the Dev's could add is that the creation will move to the direction where the mouse it pointed. That's really the only reason why I do not recommend this game to be honest, all the other issues are not really that bad.
